loans.name: Essi

texts.fr:
Mrs Essi D. is 39 years old, married and mother of three (03) children. She has been selling bananas at the bus station in Assahoun for 15 years. With her revenues, she contributes significantly to needs of her family. This business is very lucrative well run.

Translated from French by Susan Bell, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Essi D. est agée de 39 ans mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle vend des bananes à la gare routière d'Assahoun depuis plus de 15 ans. Avec ce revenu elle contribue de façon significative aux charges de la famille. Cette activité est très lucrative et gère avec propriété ses affaires

loans.use: purchase of bananas in Badou to resell them in Assahoun

loans.name: Bernadetha

texts.en:
Bernadetha M. is 59 years old and raises cattle and chickens in the rural town of Maili Moja. Both are good investments, because they yield short and long-term profits: long-term, from the sale of the whole animal and short-term, from the sale of milk and eggs. Bernadetha requires a loan of $450 to purchase additional chicks to raise and sell. She is a single mother, and her business allows her to support her four children.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional livestock (cows and chickens).

loans.name: Mwadawa

texts.en:
Since 2005, Mwadawa H. has run a business selling clothes. Her gross monthly income is approximately $180, and her monthly profit is approximately $80. She hopes to increase both figures by buying new stock in bulk, for which she requires a loan of $525. Mwadawa is 30 years old and married to husband Issa, with whom she has three children: Maabadi, 13, Rehema, 7 and Fatuma, 3.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback". SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing stock.

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr:
Mr Koffi A. is 42 years old and father of three (03) children. For the last three years, Mr. Koffi has been working in his studio situated by the road. His studio draws the attention and curiosity of several tourists who pass through the region and they are his main clients. He buys local materials in the region and after several hours of manual labor, he produces works of art that are very precious and admired by Westerners. To satisfy his many orders, Mr Koffi is asking for a loan to be able to fill them.

Translated from French by Susan Bell, Kiva Volunteer.

Mr Koffi A. est agé de 42 ans , père de 03 enfants. Depuis 3 ans Mr Koffi a installé son atélier de production des objets d'art au bord de la route. Son atelier attire la curuosité de plusieurs touristes qui passent dans la région et constitue sa principale clientèle. Il achète les matériels locaux dans la région après plusieurs heures de travail manuel il fait sortir des objets d'art très précieux et admirés par les occidentaux. Pour satisfaire les diverses commandes Mr Koffi sollicite un emprunt pour réaliser sa commande.

loans.use: purchase of wood to create works of art

loans.name: Eisha

texts.en:
Hollywood here we come! Earlier this year, Eisha M. established a video-production business which records "Kodak moments" in people’s lives; weddings, birthdays, anniversaries and graduations. In a country where getting a degree or reaching a 50th birthday are not foregone conclusions, such events are very special and people want a record of the celebration. And despite the fact that extra cash is hard to come by, people are willing to pay for such a service. This is good news for Eisha and the cameraman she employs. Eisha wants to secure her position in this field by producing high-quality videos and photographs, and for this she requires a laptop, which will cost $700, for editing and storing images . Eisha has successfully repaid two previous loans from SELFINA. She has two children with her husband Juma: Essam, 3 and Jania, 2 months.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase a laptop for editing and storing photographs and digital videos.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en:
Habiba A. runs a general store in the busy town of Maili Moja, on the outskirts of Dar es Salaam, where she sells about everything except the kitchen sink. Habiba established the business in 2005, and is requesting a loan of $350 to purchase additional stock in bulk. She and her husband Swalehe have six children, three of them grown and three under the age of 12.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her general store.

loans.name: Kuruthum

texts.en:
Since 2005, Kuruthum B. has run a general store in the rural town of Kibamba, where she sells food and items people use in their homes such as cookware. She has requested a loan of $450 to buy, in bulk, additional items she can sell in her store. Kuruthum is a single mother with two children, Zainabu, 16 and Salma, 14, and is also responsible for the care of her nephew Nicksoni, 9. She thanks you for your support.

This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback". SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase in bulk additional stocks of food and other items to sell.

loans.name: Jauna

texts.en:
Jauna S. has run a business raising and selling chickens since 2001. She has already repaid one loan from SELFINA, and has requested a second loan of $1,050 to buy additional chicks, and to extend their enclosure Jauna is a 49-year-old widow with three children: Johari, 21, Rahma, 18 and Lailagi, 14.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens and extend their enclosure.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah M. is 38 years old, married and has three children with her husband Justini: Anna, 15, Helena, 13 and Paulo, 7. Since 2002, Sarah has run a business selling charcoal. These small pieces of black, dry earth are important to Sarah and her customers, who rely on charcoal to cook their meals. Many Tanzanians still do their cooking in small coal pots in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal pieces) and add paper, dry grass, old plastic bags or kerosene to light the flame. The fire requires constant fanning, which makes cooking a hot, laborious task. It may not be the easiest or most environmentally friendly form of cooking, but it is the only option many people can afford. This is good news for Sarah, who requires a loan of $875 to add to her stock of mkaa and continue meeting customer demand.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase charcoal stock in bulk.

loans.name: Zahara

texts.en:
Zahara A. runs a hair salon in Maili Majo, a busy rural town on the outskirts of Dar es Salaam. She established the business in 2005, and has already repaid one loan from SELFINA. Zahara has applied for a new loan to purchase additional equipment and stock, such as driers, curlers, shampoo, conditioner and hairpieces. Zahara is a 38-year-old widow with three children, Fatima, 20, Shekha, 18 and Said, 16. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase equipment and haircare products for Zahara Salon

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
As she describes it, Eunice N. is in the business of selling clothes and “ndogo ndogo” (small, small) things. She hopes to increase her monthly profit of $100 by using a loan of $350 to buy additional items in bulk to sell to her customers. Eunice is 35 years old and a single mother with one son, John, who is 13.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing and other items to sell.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
With over a decade's experience running small companies, 38-year-old Saumu M. is a veteran businesswoman. In 1995, she started a company that sold bed sheets. In 2000, she established a chicken-raising business. And this year Saumu diversified further and bought a dalla dalla (a minibus, the main form of public transport in Tanzania), which is driven and managed day-to-day by an employee. Saumu requires a loan of $1,050, which she plans to use to expand the chicken-raising business. She is married to husband Nurunidi and has three children, Aziza, 14, Alfani, 8 and Rashidi, 4.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens to raise and sell.

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
For many of the women in the town of Mkuza, Dora K.’s cosmetics shop is the place to load up on items such as lipstick, eyeshadow, foundation, powder and perfume. Dora established the business earlier this year and requires a loan of $700 to increase the quantity and range of the items she has for sale. She and her husband Richard have two children, Erikson, 17 and Walter, 12. In addition to running her own business, Dora works as a warden at a local high school.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional cosmetics to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Siri

texts.en:
Amidst a flutter of feathers, Mama Shafii feeds her brood -- but her name refers to her 6 year-old son Shafii, not one of the birds she is feeding. She raises chickens for sale and requires a loan of $625 to purchase more chicks. Mama Shafii is 27 years-old and married to Shafii’s father Mohamedi.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens to raise and sell.

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Since 1998, Debora N. has established and operated a range of diverse businesses, including raising livestock, growing vegetables and running a shop that sells basic groceries such as rice. A business analyst would probably say that she has shrewdly spread her risk, which is beneficial to both her and lenders. Debora has already repaid one loan from SELFINA and now has requested another, which she plans to use to buy additional livestock. She is married and has four children with her husband Moses: Furahini, 16, Reuben, 15, Furaha, 14 and Sayuni, 3.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional livestock.

loans.name: Nasra

texts.en:
Spark plugs and spokes, tires and tubes, wheels and wipers, Nasra G. and her husband Hassan sell all these and more at their spare-parts shop in the large rural town of Maili Moja. Nasra has been running the business since 2001, and now has applied for a loan of $875 to help it continue to expand by buying additional items to sell to her customers. Nasra and Hassan have two children, Sophia, 6 and Abdulah, 16 months.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell in her spare-parts shop.

loans.name: Mabel Nely

texts.es:
Mabel Nelly, 38, has three children, ages 22, 20 and 2 years old. She has been a member of Banco Communal Solución for 8 years. During this time, she saved enough money to build a second floor in her house. She also bought appliances and cooking utensils but the most help she received from Banco Comunal was advice on how to educate her children with love and care.

In her business, Mabel sells fruit - an activity she learned from her mother when she was a little girl. Mabel buys prickly pear cactus, which is a fruit native to the region and sells it wholesale at markets in Lima. In these same markets, she also buys fruits like papaya, apples, pepino, and others that are in high demand to sell in Ayacuchan markets.

However, Mabel has another business where she sells auto spare parts from her home. She started this business 10 years ago because her husband was a mechanic. At the time, she thought about supplying the parts that her husband needed. This is how Mabel started delivering parts from Lima. Now, her store has spare parts and auto lubricants.

The loan she needs amounts to 3000 Peruvian sols. The total will be invested in boxes and barrels of car lubricants like oil from Shell. Her savings will then be used to build a third floor in her house and for her own savings. Her dream is to buy a cart to transport her load and to have her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

Mabel Nelly tiene 38 años de edad y tiene 3 hijos de 22, 20 y 2 años. Ella pertenece al Banco Comunal Solución desde hace 8 años y en este tiempo ha ahorrado lo suficiente para construir el segundo piso de su casa. Además compró sus artefactos y utensilios de cocina, pero lo que más la ayudo fueron los consejos que le dieron en su Banco Comunal sobre cómo educar a los hijos con cariño y amor.

El negocio de Mabel es la venta de fruta, actividad que aprendió de su mamá cuando era una niña. Mabel compra tuna, que es una fruta de la región y lo vende en el mercado mayorista de frutas de Lima, y a la vez, en este mercado compra frutas como papaya, manzana, pepino y otras frutas que tienen mayor demanda en el mercado ayacuchano y los vende.

Mabel además realiza otro negocio en paralelo, que es la venta de repuestos de autos, actividad que realiza en su casa. Hace 10 años inició este negocio porque su esposo era mecánico y pensó en proveer ella misma los repuestos que necesitaba su esposo. Fue así que Mabel comenzó a traer repuestos de Lima y ahora tiene su tienda de repuestos y lubricantes.

El préstamo que necesita es de 3000 soles, monto que será invertido en la compra de lubricantes como aceite Shell en cajas y en baldes. Lo que ahorre lo utilizará en la construcción del tercer piso de su casa y también para tener un capital propio. Su sueño es comprar un carro para transportar sus cargas y que sus hijos sean buenos profesionales.

loans.use: The loan she needs will be invested in boxes and barrels of car lubricants like oil from Shell.

loans.name: Margarita's Group

texts.es:
Margarita, Sara, and Maria Elena have been partners in the communal bank “Paloma” for two, three, and eight years respectively. Margarita and Maria Elena are single, while Sara lives with her partner and has three children. At first, Margarita ran a bar, but after observing that her neighbors requested other products, she decided to turn her business into a grocery store. On the other hand, Sara sells all-natural Omnilife products and also has a hardware store in the city of Lima, which is run by her husband. Maria Elena sells fruit, an activity that she has performed for ten years in the Nery García Zarate market in Ayacucho. Their loans are for 400 soles, 2000 soles, and 400 soles respectively, which will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, eggs, milk, plantains, mangos, grapes, apples, and Omnilife products. They will use their savings to purchase display cases, tools, and to handle any family emergency that may arise. Margarita, Sara, and Maria Elena say that in the communal bank, they practice values such as team spirit and punctuality, and the colleagues are very united and support each other whenever one has a problem. Margarita’s, Sara’s, and Maria Elena’s dreams are to have a mini-market, a hardware store, a restaurant in the countryside, and a shop of her own.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Margarita, Sara y Maria Elena son socias del Banco Comunal Paloma desde hace 2, 3 y 8 años respectivamente. Margarita y Maria Elena son solteras, mientras que Sara es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos. En un inicio, Margarita tenía un bar, pero al observar que sus vecinos pedían otros productos decidió implementar su negocio en una bodega. Por otro lado Sara vende productos Omnilife, que son productos naturales y además tiene una ferretería en la ciudad de Lima, el cual es administrado por su esposo. Mientras que el negocio de Maria Elena es la venta de frutas, actividad que realiza desde hace 10 años en el mercado Nery García Zarate en Ayacucho. Sus préstamos son de 400 soles, 2000 soles y 400 soles respectivamente, los cuales serán invertidos en la compra de arroz, azúcar, huevo, leche, plátano, mango, uva, manzana y productos Omnilife. Sus ahorros los utilizarán para comprar vitrinas, artefactos y para alguna emergencia que se pueda presentar en la familia. Margarita, Sara y Maria Elena dicen que en su Banco Comunal se práctica los valores como la solidaridad, la puntualidad y las socias son muy unidas y se apoyan cuando alguien tiene algún problema. Los sueños de Margarita, Sara y Maria Elena son tener un minimarket, una ferretería, un restaurante campestre y un local propio.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstock, fruits, and Omnilife products for their respective stores

loans.name: Dina's Group

texts.es:
Haydee is 32 years old and has two children; Irma is 35 years old and has three children, and Dina L. is 38 years old and has five children. They are all partners in the Paloma Communal Bank. At first, Dina sold beverages on the street, but later she rented a small stand to sell chicharrones, a traditional pork dish. She currently has a restaurant selling chicharrones in a large and more comfortable space. Haydee sells food in the bus terminal, and has previous sold orange juice, fruits, and vegetables to get to where she is today. Today, she is thinking about renting another stand to sell fruits. Irma has a kiosk located in front of the Regional Hospital of Ayacucho where she sells food and drink as well as selling clothing at her customers’ requests. These women need loans of 400 soles, 1500 soles, and 400 soles that will be invested in purchasing meat, soft drinks, wine, undergarments, shoes, shirts and in opening an additional fruit stand.

Dina, Haydee and Irma say that in the communal bank, they have learned to be on time, to save and to value good customer service. They have large dreams, including running a large restaurant selling ceviche, having her own store, giving their children the best of life, and being professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Haydee tiene 32 años y 2 hijos, Irma tiene 35 años y 3 hijos, mientras que L. tiene 38 años y 5 hijos, y todas son socias del Banco Comunal Paloma. Dina en un inicio vendía moliente, era ambulante, pero posteriormente alquiló un local pequeño para vender “Chicharrones”, comida típica preparada con carne de cerdo. Actualmente ella tiene una “Chicharronería” (Restaurante que vende Chicharrones) en un local más grande y cómodo. Haydee vende comida en el terminal terrestre y para llegar a tener este negocio ella hizo diferentes actividades como venta de jugo de naranja, verduras y frutas. Ahora ella tiene pensado alquilar otro puesto para la venta de frutas. Irma tiene un kiosco ubicado al frente del Hospital Regional de Ayacucho donde vende comida y bebidas y, además ella vende ropa de acuerdo a los pedidos de sus clientes. Ellas necesitan préstamos de 400 soles, 1500 soles y 400 soles que serán invertidos en la compra de carne, gaseosas, vino, ropas interiores, zapatos, polos y también para implementar otro puesto de venta de frutas. Dina, Haydee e Irma dicen que en su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser puntuales, a ahorrar y a cómo tratar al cliente. Sus sueños son muchos como tener una cebichería en un local grande, un local propio, darle lo mejor a los hijos y que sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase food and clothing for resale, and open a new fruit stand.

loans.name: Donata

texts.es:
Donata lives with her husband and 3 children. She is 43 years old and she was born in Huancapi, Department of Ayacucho. Donata says that when she made her home she went to live in Matará, the hometown of her husband, where she set up her restaurant business and grocery. It went well, but as her children grew they needed to study in the city of Ayacucho. It was then that she went to Ayacucho with her children, leaving her business under the administration of her husband. Subsequently he had to close his business. At present she is an exhibitor. She sells food in the fair of Seccelambras and Matará. She buys animals and fattens them for subsequent sale in Ayacucho. She also sells cheese and now she is going to open a restaurant in Chontaca.

Donata has been an associate of the Dove Communal Bank for 5 years and in this time she learned to save and to be responsible. The loan that she needs is 1000 soles. It will be invested in the new business that she plans to start and will buy tables, chairs, kitchen utensils, rice and sugar. Donata’s dreams are to have a pretty house, to buy a car and that their children be professionals.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Donata vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Ella tiene 43 años ella y nació en Huancapi, Departamento de Ayacucho. Donata cuenta que cuando formó su hogar se fue a vivir a Matará, pueblo natal de su esposo, donde instaló su negocio de restaurante y tienda de abarrotes. Le fue bien, pero como sus hijos iban creciendo tenían que estudiar en la ciudad de Ayacucho. Fue entonces que ella se fue a Ayacucho con sus hijos, dejando su negocio en administración de su esposo. Posteriormente tuvo que cerrar su negocio.

Actualmente ella es feriante; vende comida en la feria de Seccelambras y Matará, compra animales y los engorda para posteriormente venderlos en Ayacucho. También vende queso y ahora ella va a abrir un restaurante en Chontaca. Donata es socia del Banco Comunal Paloma desde hace 5 años y en este tiempo aprendió a ahorrar y a ser responsable. El préstamo que necesita es de 1000 soles que serán invertidos en el nuevo negocio que piensa implementar y comprará mesas, sillas, utensilios de cocina, arroz y azúcar. Los sueños que tiene son tener una casa bonita, comprar un carro y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: To invest in a new business that Donata plans to start and to buy tables, chairs, kitchen utensils, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma is 35 years old. She has two children and is her family’s only source of income. She has been an associate of the Lila Communal Bank for 3 years, and says that it helped her very much with the loans that they gave her immediately upon signing. She also says she has learned the value of punctuality and responsibility.

Vilma purchases footwear for all ages in the city of Lima and then sells it in the province of Andahuaylas in Apurimac. She has been running this business for 8 years now. She needs a loan of 1000 soles which will be invested in the purchase of shoes, sandals and slippers.

Vilma has been saving for the future of her children and to make an improvement in her home. Vilma dreams of having a store in Ayacucho, owning her own capital, and that her children are professionals and useful to society.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Vilma tiene 35 años y 2 hijos y es el único sustento de su familia. Ella es socia del Banco Comunal Lila desde hace 3 años y dice que su Banco Comunal le ayudó mucho con los préstamos que le dieron a sola firma, además, que ha aprendido los valores de la puntualidad y responsabilidad. Vilma compra calzados para toda edad en Lima y los vende en la provincia de Andahuaylas, departamento de Apurimac, y realiza este negocio desde hace 8 años. El préstamo que necesita es de 1000 soles que serán invertidos en la compra de zapatos, sandalias y zapatillas. Vilma viene ahorrando para el futuro de sus hijos y para hacer una mejora en su casa. Los sueños de Vilma son tener una tienda en Ayacucho, un capital propio y que sus hijos sean profesionales y útiles para la sociedad.

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of shoes, sandals and slippers.

loans.name: Asunta's Group

texts.es:
Águeda, Asunta and Felicitas are associates of the Enthusiasts Communal Bank. Águeda is 70 years old and has 4 children and a grocery store in her own house located in the City of Cumana. Águeda has run this business since 1987. On the other hand, Asunta is 50 years old and has 6 children. She buys firewood in Vilcashuamán and sells it on Las Malvinas Avenue. Previously she was a washerwoman and sold food. Felicitas is 42 years old and has 3 children. Her business is to buy and to sell cochinilla (a red dye) and tara (a powder used in tanning). She goes to the fairs and communities to buy the cochinilla and resells it to the wholesalers. During the carnival, in February, she prepares a liquor of seven seeds that is maD. with corn, wheat, beans, arveja (a legume), goosefoot (an herb), kiwicha (a grain grown in the Andes) and chickpea. She sells this liquor in the stadiums where the carnival extras are organized.

Águeda, Asunta and Felicitas tell us that in their Communal Bank they are all like sisters. They have learned to save. With the loans they buy with cash and no longer have to pay surcharges like before when they bought with credit. Their loans of 400 soles, 800 soles and 400 soles will be invested in the purchase of tara, cochinilla, carbonated water, milk, noodles, firewood, and cereals.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Águeda, Asunta y Felicitas son socias del Banco Comunal Las Entusiastas. Águeda tiene 70 años y 4 hijos, y tiene una tienda D. abarrotes en su propia casa ubicada en la Ciudad D. Cumana. Águeda realiza este negocio desD. 1987. Por otro lado Asunta tiene 50 años y 6 hijos. Ella compra leña en Vilcashuamán y la venD. en la Av. Las Malvinas. Anteriormente ella era lavandera y vendía comida. Felicitas tiene 42 años y 3 hijos, y su negocio es comprar y vender cochinilla, tara. Ella va a las ferias y comunidades a comprar la cochinilla y lo revenD. a los mayoristas. Durante el carnaval, en febrero, ella prepara chicha D. siete semillas, que está hecha a base D. maíz, trigo, haba, arveja, quinua, kiwicha y garbanzo. VenD. esta chicha en los estadios donD. se organizan las comparsas D. carnaval.

Águeda, Asunta y Felicitas nos cuentan que en su Banco Comunal todas son como hermanas y aprendieron a ahorrar y con los préstamos compran al contado y ya no tienen que pagar recargos como antes cuando compraban al crédito. Sus préstamos son D. 400 soles, 800 soles y 400 soles que lo invertirán en la compra D. tara, cochinilla, gaseosa, leche, fideo, leña, cereales. Los sueños D. Águeda, Asunta, Felicitas son tener casa propia y D. material noble, educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales y que su negocio aumente.

loans.use: Purchase of tara (a powder used in tanning), cochinilla (a red dye), carbonated water, milk, noodles, firewood and cereals.

loans.name: Irma Garcia Cajamarca's Group

texts.es:
Margarita, Irma and DomitiL. have been partners of the Banco Comunal Las Entusiastas for nine, two and nine years, respectively. They tell us that the Banco Comunal helps them by giving them capital for their businesses and, as a result, they can take care of their homes. In addition, they have learned how to be punctual and responsible. Margarita cultivates and sells fruit and ornamental plants and flowers in a spot in the Cooperativa D. las Americas. She sells at wholesale and retail prices. Meanwhile, DomitiL. prepares and sells ceviche by wandering at the Huanta station. Previously, she traveled to markets with vegetables and fruits but she stopped this activity due to health problems. On the other hand, Irma sells Esika beauty products which she offers to friends and family. These women need loans of 600 soles, 300 soles and 400 soles which will be invested in the purchase of ornamental plants brought from Lima such as ficus, tulips, and roses, as well as in gardening tools, perfumes, lipsticks, nail polish, shampoo and fish. They will use their savings to educate their children and improve their homes. Margarita, Irma and Domitilia’s dreams are that their children become professionals, better than them, and that they can make improvements to their homes.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Margarita, Irma y DomitiL. son socias del Banco Comunal Las Entusiastas desD. hace 9, 2, y 9 años respectivamente. Ellas cuentan que su Banco Comunal las ayuda dándoles capital para su negocio y así pueden mantener sus hogares. Además, dicen haber aprendido a ser puntuales y responsables. Margarita cultiva y venD. plantas ornamentales, frutales y flores en un puesto en L. Cooperativa D. las Américas, venD. al por mayor y menor. Mientras que DomitiL. prepara y venD. cebiche ambulantemente en el paradero a Huanta. Anteriormente elL. viajaba a las ferias llevando verduras, frutas, pero dejó D. hacer esta actividad porque esta mal D. salud. Por otro lado Irma venD. productos D. belleza Esika que ofrece a sus amigos y familiares. Ellas necesitan un préstamo D. 600 soles, 300 soles y 400 soles que serán invertidos en L. compra D. plantas ornamentales que trae D. Lima como ficus, tulipán, rosas enanas, injertos, maceteros, perfumes, lápices labiales, esmalte, champú y pescado. Sus ahorros los utilizarán en L. educación D. sus hijos y para mejorar su casa. Los sueños D. Margarita, Irma y DomitiL. son que sus hijos sean profesionales, mejores que ellas y poder hacer mejoras en sus casas.

loans.use: This group needs loans of 600 soles, 300 soles and 400 soles which will be invested in the purchase of ornamental plants brought from Lima such as ficus, tulips, and roses, as well as in gardening tools, perfumes, lipsticks, nail polish, shampoo and fish.

loans.name: Sebastiana's Group

texts.es:
Sebastiana is 64 years old, has 4 children and is a widow, while Edward is 30 years old, has 2 children and is separated. They have been associates of the Enthusiasts Communal Bank for 4 years and 1 year, respectively.

Sebastiana buys cereals in the fairs and sells them at the Marshal Cáceres Market . She says that she became a widow when her children were small, and, as she could not work her lands alone, she came to live in Ayacucho.

On the other hand, Edward is a driver for public transportation and also he has his nursery of grafts and vegetables. Previously Edward had a car which he used to proviD. transportation for a school in the city, but this failed because of family problems.

They need loans of 600 Peruvian soles each (total of 1,200) that will be invested in the purchase of corn, bean, barley, wheat, seeds and a part for food processing for health.

Sebastián and Edward tell us that at their Communal Bank they are distracted from their troubles: they forget for a moment their problems, they get to know more people and they also save.

Sebastiana and Edward’s dreams are to build a house, to open a store and to buy a car so that Edward can once more proviD. school transportation.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Sebastiana tiene 64 años, 4 hijos y es viuda, mientras que Edward tiene 30 años, 2 hijos y es separado. Ambos son socios del Banco Comunal Las Entusiastas desD. hace 4 años y 1 año, respectivamente.

Sebastiana compra cereales en las ferias y venD. en un puesto del Mercado Mariscal Cáceres. ElL. cuenta que quedó viuda cuando sus hijos eran pequeños, y como no podía trabajar soL. sus tierras se vino a vivir a Ayacucho.

Por otro lado Edward es conductor D. una unidad D. transporte público y también tiene su vivero D. injertos y hortalizas. Anteriormente Edward tenía su carro con el cual hacía movilidad escolar en un colegio D. L. ciudad, pero fracasó por problemas familiares.

Ellos necesitan préstamos D. 600 soles, cada uno (total D. 1,200) que serán invertidos en L. compra D. maíz, fréjol, cebada, trigo, semillas y una parte para el tratamiento D. su salud.

Sebastián y Edward nos cuenan que en su Banco Comunal ellos se distraen y olvidan por un momento sus problemas, conocen más personas y también ahorran.

Los sueños D. Sebastiana y Edward son construir su casa, abrir una tienda y comprar su carro para volver hacer movilidad escolar.

loans.use: Purchase of  corn, bean, barley, wheat, seeds and a part for food processing for health.

loans.name: Felicitas Janampa Quispe's Group

texts.es:
Wilfredo, Felicitas and Lurdivina are partners of the Banco Comunal Proyección. Wilfredo has one son and his business is providing filming and photography service at different events and family get togethers that hire him. He is also a reporter for television and the region’s newspaper. Meanwhile, Felicitas has five children and she sells typical food like chicharrón (crackling), chuño, which is dried potatoes, morcilla which is sausage prepared with pig’s blood, aromatic herbs and rice. Felicitas also works at the market selling breads, fruits, and animal curd which comes from the organs of sheep and pigs and is used to add flavor to cheese. She will also sell Christmas bread during the holidays. On the other side, Lurdivina has seven children and she sells fish at the local market. She also sells cheese and, at the holidays, Christmas bread. They need loans of 600 soles, 1,000 soles and 600 soles which will be invested in purchases of film, tape, chuño, potatoes, meat, Christmas bread, fish and cheese. Their dreams are to have bigger businesses, a good education for their children, their own house, and a car.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Wilfredo, Felicitas y Lurdivina son socios del Banco Comunal Proyección. Wilfredo tiene 1 hijo y su negocio es servicio de filmación y fotografías en diferentes eventos y compromisos familiares que lo contraten y también es reportero para la televisión y boletín informativo de la región. Mientras que Felicitas tiene 5 hijos y vende comida típica como chicharrón, chuño, que es papa deshidratada y, morcilla que es un embutido preparado con la sangre del cerdo, hierbas aromáticas y arroz. Felicitas también es feriante y lleva panes, frutas y cuajo de animal que proviene de la víscera del carnero y cerdo, el cual es utilizado para elaborar queso. Además, por campaña navideña venderá panetones. Por otro lado Lurdivina tiene 7 hijos y vende pescado en las ferias, también vende queso y por campaña navideña venderá panetones. Ellos necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 1000 soles y 600 soles que serán invertidos en la compra de rollos, cintas, chuño, papa, carne, panetones, pescado y queso. Los sueños que tienen son tener un negocio mas grande, una buena educación para sus hijos, casa propia, un carro.

loans.use: They need loans of 600 soles, 1000 soles, and 600 soles which will be invested in the purchase of film, tape, chuño (dried potato), potatoes, meat, Christmas bread, fish and cheese.

loans.name: Gladys Marisol's Group

texts.es:
Romulo, Liliana and Gladis are members of the Communal Projection Bank.

Liliana is 25 years old and sells clothes for all ages in the fairs. She learned this activity from her mother-in-law who taught her where to buy and where to sell. Romulo sells electrical appliances, such as televisions and DVD players which are acquired through Custom's liquidations and are distributed in the stores of Ayacucho. While Gladis is 33 years old and sells clothes that she brings from Lima in the fairs of Seccelambras.

Their loans are for 100 soles (Peruvian currency), 600 soles and 450 soles respectively and will be invested in the purchase of pants, shirts, polos, socks and undergarments and to pay for the transport of their merchandise from Lima to Ayacucho.

Romulo, Liliana and Gladis say that the Communal Bank helps them because it gives them loans at the time that they are needed and also trains them on different topics.

Their savings will be used in the case of an emergency and Gladis will use them for an operation that she needs due to her poor health.

Their dreams are to formalize their businesses, to have a business that imports, to educate their children so that they become professionals, to have capital and to open a store.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Conover, Kiva volunteer.

Rómulo, Liliana y Gladis son socios del Banco Comunal Proyección. Liliana tiene 25 años y vende ropa para todas las edades en las ferias. Ella aprendió esta actividad de su suegra, quien le enseño dónde comprar y dónde vender. Por otro lado Rómulo vende artefactos eléctricos como televisores, DVD, que son adquiridos en los remates de Aduanas y los distribuye en las tiendas de Ayacucho. Mientras que Gladis tiene 33 años y vende ropa, que trae de Lima, en las ferias de Seccelambras. Sus préstamos son de 1000 soles, 600 soles y 450 soles respectivamente y serán invertidos en la compra de pantalones, ropones, camisas, polos, chompas, calcetines, ropas interiores y para el pago del transporte de su mercadería, de Lima a Ayacucho. Rómulo, Liliana y Gladis dicen que su Banco Comunal les ayuda porque les da préstamos en el momento que necesitan, y también los capacitan en diferentes temas. Sus ahorros lo utilizarán en alguna emergencia que pueda ocurrir en casa y Gladis lo usará para su operación ya que se encuentra mal de salud. Sus sueños son formalizar su negocio, poner un tienda importadora, educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales, tener capital y abrir una tienda.

loans.use: To buy pants, shirts, socks and undergarments, as well as to pay for transport to the market (between Lima and Ayacucho)

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
María Magdalena D. is a single woman with five children, four of which are school age. Her children have been her reason for living and they are the reason she has made such an effort, giving them an education for the future so they may improve their standard of living.

17 years ago she dedicated herself to the sale of tortillas, but then found a better opportunity in her path and in this way she began her business selling clothing bought wholesale and then sold individually.

This business is one of the most outstanding today. Her sales have increased over the years, and while before she placed her product with daily payments, she now has a fixed stall with the income obtained by expanding and improving considerably. Her initial capital was C$20,000 (Córdobas), which she had saved.

María Magdalena has worked with CEPRODEL for two years and is very satisfied because the credits that they have granted her have been timely and she’s been able to buy business necessities and satisfy customer demand. She has a record of 20 credits.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

María Magdalena D. es una mujer soltera con cinco hijos, de los cuales cuatro se encuentran en edad escolar. Sus hijos han sido la razón de vivir y por ello es que ella se ha esforzado, brindándoles así una educación para el futuro de ellos mejorando así su nivel de vida.

Hace 17 años se dedicaba a venta de tortillas, sin embargo logro una mejor oportunidad en su camino y fue así que ella da inicio a su negocio de venta de ropa donde compra al mayorista y vende al detalle.

Este negocio es uno de los más destacados hoy en día sus ventas han incrementado al paso de los años antes colocaba el producto con abonos diarios, actualmente tiene puesto fijo con los ingresos obtenidos ya que ella ha ido ampliándolo y mejorando considerablemente. Su inicio capital fue C $ 20,000.00 (Córdobas)los cuales eran de ahorro.

María Magdalena trabajo con CEPRODEL desde hace dos años y se siente muy satisfecha ya que los créditos que se le han otorgado brindados estos en momento oportuno ayudándola así a suplir necesidades del negocio y satisfacer a diario a su clientela. Ella tiene un récor de 20 créditos.

loans.use: Buy clothing merchandise

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
María Magdalena D. is a single woman with five children, four of which are of school age. Her children have been her reason for living and it is for them that she has striven, providing them an education so that they will have a better standard of living in the future.

Seventeen years ago, she sold tortillas, nevertheless she found a better opportunity in her path and through this she began her business selling clothing. She buys at wholesale and sells at retail.

This business is one of the most prominent today. Her sales have increased over the years. Currently, with the revenue she has earned, she has a fixed spot which she has been expanding and improving considerably. Her initial capital was C$20,000.00 (Cordobas) which came from savings.

María Magdalena has worked with CEPRODEL for two years. She feels very satisfied since the credits she has been granted were provided at an opportune moment helping her fulfill necessities for the business and satisfy her customers daily. She has a record of 20 credits.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

María Magdalena D. es una mujer soltera con cinco hijos, de los los cuales cuatro se encuentran en edad escolar. Sus hijos han sido la razón de vivir y por ello es que ella se ha esforzado, brindandoles asi una eduación para el futuro de ellos mejorando asi su nivel de vida.

Hace 17 años se dedicaba a venta de tortillas, sin embargo logro una mejor oportunidad en su camino y fue asi que ella da inicio a su negocio de venta de ropa donde compra al mayorista y vende al detalle,.

Este negocio es uno de los más destacados hoy en día sus ventas han incrementado al paso de los años antes colocaba el producto con abonos diarios, actualmente tiene puesto fijo con los ingresos obtenidos ya que ella ha ido ampliandodolo y mejorando considerablemente. Su inicio capital fue C $ 20,000.00 (Córdobas)los cuales eran de ahorro.

María Magdalena trabajo con CEPRODEL desde hace dos años y se siente muy satisfecha ya que los creditos que se le han otorgado brindados estos en momento oportuno ayudandola asi a suplir necesidades del negocio y satisfacer a diario a su clientela. Ella tiene un recor de 20 creditos.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise.

loans.name: Rafaela

texts.en:
Rafaela is a businesswoman that had to work hard to care for her daughter.  The daughter is now grown up and is married.  Rafaela lives with her partner, a farmer.

Rafaela runs a small grocery store.  The store is very useful in the community because people don’t have to walk far to get the goods they need to prepare food.  The entrepreneur says her neighbors are very thankful and that she has been very satisfied for many years, serving others.

The entrepreneur is requesting funds to get goods to replenish her store. She says that during the holidays, people need more products. She hopes she can increase her sales volume and have money saved away for unforeseen circumstances.

loans.use: Replenish a small grocery to keep on satisfying the customers' needs.

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
Martha Lorena M. is a single woman with 4 children, who have been her greatest motivation to begin a business. While stabilizing her own business, she can give her family a good future and help them improve their standard of living.

Before beginning her business, she dedicated herself to helping her parents’ business for months. Once she began her own business, she started in a market, and then moved up to the Market Terminal and obtained a fixed stand with a better structure.

Currently, the infrastructure of her business does not meet the need to protect her products from the sun and rain, taking into account that they are perishable products and they require more care and hygiene. However, her project is to buy merchandise in order to supply her business with more and, at the same time, invest her earnings in infrastructure so she may gain a better presence at the market which will attract more customers.

Martha Lorena started her business with savings in the initial amount of CS 1,000.00 (Cordobas). She has worked with CEPRODEL for two years granting her 33 credits, which have helped her grow her finances and improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Martha Lorena M. es una mujer soltera con 4 hijos, los cuales han sido su mayor animación para emprender en un negocio y asi darle un buen futuro a su familia al igual que estabilizar su propio negocio ayudandole a mejorar su nivel de vida.

Antes de dar inicio a su negocio ella se dedicaba ayudando al negocio de sus padres por meses. Al dar inicio a su propio negocio empezó en mercado, luego pasó al Mercado la Terminal logrando tener su puesto fijo mejorando asi la estructura del mismo .

Actualmente la infraestructura de su negocio no cubre con las necesidad de proteger sus productos del sol y la lluvia, tomando en cuenta que son productos perecederos y requieren de un mayor cuidado e higiene. Pero su proyecto es comprar la mercaderia para surtir mas su negocio y al mismo tiempo con las ganancias invertir en infraestructura para una mejor presencia en el mercado y atraer mayor clientela

Martha Lorena dio inicio a su negocio con ahorros con un monto inicial de CS 1,000.00 (Córdobas). Ha trabajado con CEPRODEL desee hace dos años, otorgandole 33 créditos, los cuales le han ayudado a crecer sus finanzas y mejoramiento del mismo negocio.

loans.use: Buy merchandise.

loans.name: Rosario Angelina

texts.es:
Rosario Angelica S. is a single mother with one school-aged son. Over 20 years, she has dedicated herself to the sale of fruit and vegetables, conducting purchases directly from producers while her sales are performed at wholesale and retail.

Rosario began her business with savings in the amount of C$1,500.00 Cordobas (approximately US $80.00) at the local Station Market. Currently, her business can be found in the Terminal Market in the city of León.

CEPRODEL has granted her credits for two and a half years totaling 33 credits with which Rosario has obtained earnings so she can fill her home with all the necessities. She is asking for a new credit so that she can improve the infrastructure of her business since the current construction is four blocks of wood and a zinc roof. Investing in this manner will allow her to attract more customers and she will be in a better position to keep her products in good shape. In addition, she will be able to invest in purchases of oranges and “mamón chino” (a Nicaraguan tropical fruit). To Rosario, it will be compliment that you allow her to grow her business and her existing capital through your assistance.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosario Angelica S. es una madre soltera con un hijo en edad escolar. Durante 20 años se ha dedicado al negocio de ventas de verduras y frutas, realizando compras directamente a productores y su ventas las realiza al por mayor y al detalle.

Ella dió inicio a su negocio con un monto de ahorros de C$ 1,500.00 cordobas(aproximadamente $80 dólares), intalando su negocio en el Mercado la Estación con su local fijo. Actualmente su negocio se encuentra en el mercado la Terminal de la ciudad de León.

CEPRODEL le ha otrogado creditos desde hace dos años y medio con un total de 33 creditos con los cuales a obtenido ganancias para poder suplir las necesidades en su hogar. Ella solicita un nuevo credito para poder tener mejor infraestructura en su negocio ya que la construcion actual es de 4 bloques de madera y un techo de zinc. Invirtiendo de esta manera, podra atraer más clientelas y asi estará en mejores condiciones para mantener sus proctuctos en buen estado; tambien logrará invertir en compras de naranjas y mamón chino (frutas tropicales nicaragüenses). Al contar con la ayuda de ustedes, será para ella un complemento que le permitirá hacer crecer su negocio y su capital de trabajo existente.

loans.use: Buy products for the market.

loans.name: Esperanza Del Socorr

texts.es:
Esperanza del Socorro L. owns a shop at the Leon market. She has built her business with a lot of effort as she does not have a family and has therefore needed to survive without a family support.

She sells plastics and electric appliances on credit. She started with the business 17 years ago as a street vendor until she could get her own shop at the Leon market.

As she didn’t have a family support, she got a credit with CEPRODEL and ever since she has been able to witness a growth in her business which has allowed her to compete with other sellers and stand out due to her sells and the infrastructure of her shop.

It is important to mention that Mrs Lopez started with a capital of C$ 50,000 (2700 USD) and nowadays, 3 years after she got the credit, she has had a lot of success developing into an efficient competitor on the market of electric appliances.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Esperanza del Socorro L. es una dama el cual posee un negocio en el mercado de Leon. Actualmente ha podido construir su puesto de venta a base de mucho esfuerzo ya que no posee familia y por lo tanto ha sobrevivido sin el apoyo familiar.

El negocio al que se dedica la Sra. Socorro L. es a la venta al crédito de plásticos y electrodomésticos iniciando este negocio hace 17 años por medio de ventas ambulantes hasta llegar a tener su propio local en el mercado de Leon.

Por la ausencia del apoyo familiar, la Sra. L. decidió realizar un préstamo en CEPRODEL de manera que a partir de haber realizado dicho préstamo, ha podido contemplar un crecimiento en su negocio pudiendo de esta manera competir con otros negociantes y sobresaliendo en sus productos e infraestructura de su local.

Cabe señalar que la Sra. Lopez inicio con un capital de C$ 50,000 y hoy en día con tres años de tener crédito en Ceproidel, ha alcanzado grandes logros en su negocio convirtiéndose en una eficiente competidora en el mercado de electrodomésticos.

loans.use: Buy electric appliances to resell them on credit

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es:
Ms. Teresa de Jesus Hernández is a single mother with 3 children, who need to continue their studies at their young age and are not yet able to work.

At present Ms. H. has a business selling clothes in the central market of Chinandega which she was able to start after she decided to request a loan from Ceprodel. Before that she was a domestic worker.

Ms. H. today marks 2 and a half years of completing loans with Ceprodel, which she states has lead to major achievements in her business such as growing sales. For that reason she has decided to continue working with the financing that Ceprodel offers to be able to maintain her 3 children.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Teresa de Jesus Hernández es una madre soltera que posee 3 hijos de los cuales tiene la necesidad de mantener sus estudios por su corta edad ya que aun no tienen capacidad para trabajar.

Actualmente la Sra. H. posee un negocio de venta de ropa en el mercado central de Chinandega el cual para poder llegar a tener este negocio inició como trabajadora domestica hasta que decidió realizar un prestamo a Ceprodel.

La sra. H. hoy en dia posee 2 años y medio de realizar prestamos con ceprodel por lo que afirma ha alcanzado grandes logros en su negocio como lo es el incremetno de las ventas y por este motivo ha decidido seguir trabajando con el financiamiento que Ceprodel le otorga para poder mantener a sus 3 hijos.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Lilieni

texts.en:
Lilieni is married with no children. She just left school and didn’t have a job, and she decided to start her ice-cake business.

She applied for this loan in order to buy ingredients for her ice-cake (popsicles in a bag) business. She sells them in the village daily, but mostly at the village school first. She is very interested in her business and wishes to continue it in the future.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her ice cake business

loans.name: Sopo

texts.en:
Sopo is a lady of 33 years with a son. She’s not married. She applied for this loan in order to buy chemicals and tools for her business.

She sells crops from her plantation at the market two days per week and she earns a profit of $96 USD ($240 ST) per day . She also works on her vegetable garden as well to supplement her income. She hopes her next loan will help in expanding the plantation and maintain her success.

loans.use: To buy tools and chemicals for her plantation

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en:
Faafetai is married with four children, and she’s 45 years old. She applied for this loan (her first) in order to buy needed stock for her shop.

She is very happy at the moment because she has an opportunity to get financial help through loans from this program, which will help in running her business. She said her next loans will be used for running and improving her business and she hopes to stay in it a long time.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Suititi

texts.en:
Suititi is married with ten children, and she’s 45 years old. She is very interested in working on her potted plants business, which she has been doing for three years. She applied for this loan (her second) in order to buy tools and add more new plants.

Most of her clients come over to her house and buy her plants. She earns about $100 USD ($250 ST) per week from her business or more if she has many clients that week. She also wishes to grow her green plants through her loans so the plants look pretty and she can get more money for them.

loans.use: To buy new tools and plants for her potted plants business

loans.name: Maria Onolina

texts.en:
Maria is a lady of 26 years and is married with two kids. She applied for this loan in order to improve and put more effort into her business.

She sells her produce at the market every weekend and makes a profit of $56 USD ($140 ST) per day, but if she needs more money for family commitments, then she delivers her produce around the village. She said that this business of hers is very helpful for earning money for different needs, but especially for her children.

loans.use: To buy tools and chemicals for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Tuaoi

texts.en:
Tuaoi is a woman of 52 years and is married with two kids. She has been running her business for about two years. It sometimes goes well and sometimes goes poorly, because there is not always enough money to buy some of the ingredients needed.

Therefore, she applied for this loan in order to buy the ingredients she needs to run the business. She delivers baked goods at shops in town and sometimes at the village. She works for three days per week, but if she has a lot of orders, then she works for four days.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her baked goods

loans.name: Bertha

texts.en:
Bertha is a lady of 33 years and is married with four children. She applied for this loan in order to buy ingredients needed for her ice-cakes (popsicles in a bag), such as sugar, cordials and plastic cups and paper.

She sells them at the village school every day and at her house throughout the whole week. She said this loan will help her run her business, and the business helps cover her family's needs, especially those of her children. She wants to pay off her current loan early and apply for the next loan to buy a big freezer for her business.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her ice-cake business

loans.name: Monika

texts.en:
Monika is a lady of 37 years and is married with four children. She has maintained her kava garden for a long time, which is the only source of income she can earn to help out with her family's needs.

This business is very important, and kava is one of the most valuable assets in Samoan culture. It is used for kava ceremonies during the village council or even a welcoming ceremony, and it’s seldom seen on Samoan farms.

She applied for this loan to buy chemicals needed for the kava plantation, but the rest is for repairing their house. Her business is very helpful to pay for her family's needs, but especially for her kids.

loans.use: To buy supplies and chemicals for her kava plantation as well as for home improvement

loans.name: Faitele

texts.en:
Faitele is a lady of 22 years and is married with a son. She just left school and is without a job, and she is helping her husband to run a taxi service.

She applied for this loan in order to buy taxi parts, such as a set of tires and a fuel pump. Her husband is the one driving the taxi, but she helps out with things like the repairs.

They make about $80 USD ($200ST) per day and operate the whole week except Sundays. She is glad that the taxi service provides so much help for her family's needs and expenses.

loans.use: To buy parts for her taxi

loans.name: Savaliga

texts.en:
Savaliga is a lady of 42 years who is single, but she’s the key person in her family providing for family expenses and needs. She is one of the longest-involved members of the program, because she has paid back six loans. She is honest in paying her weekly repayments.

She applied for this loan in order to buy prizes for her bingo business and the rest will pay for remaking her family bathroom and toilet in the European style. She said that this program provides a lot for running her business. Without the program, she could not make it, and she’s thankful for the loans and appreciates the help very much.

loans.use: To buy the prizes for her bingo hall business and also for home improvements

loans.name: Eveligi

texts.en:
Eveligi is a lady of 24 years and married with two kids. She applied for this loan in order to buy new fishing gear for her husband, who is the one who goes fishing and gets sea shells to sell to earn money.

She sells her fish strings at the village three days a week, but on Sunday mornings she sells them to the fish market at Apia (a town) where most people come and buy fish. She usually earns $48 USD ($120ST) per day, but $80 USD ($200ST) on Sundays. She likes to do her business every week, because this is the only way she earns money for her family's needs.

loans.use: To buy fishing gear

loans.name: Eseta Ah

texts.en:
Eseta is married with two kids, and she’s 32 years old. She is very talented in sewing different types of clothes, which she learned from her mother.

She applied for this loan in order to buy an industrial sewing machine to replace the hand sewing machine she started with, which is very slow. The rest is for buying materials.

Most of her clients come over to her place and give her their things to sew, but if it's slow, then she sews and sells at the flea market. This business helps her family in different ways, and that’s why she is staying on top of her business.

loans.use: To buy tools and materials for her sewing business

loans.name: Lonise

texts.en:
Lonise is a lady of 41 years and is married with three children. She applied for this loan in order to buy food and ingredients needed for running her business. She sells food at the school every day and at stores near her house on weekends. She earns around $64 USD ($160 ST) per day, but more on weekends.

She said she is very happy with her business, because it gives her much help and the money is used to meet her family's needs, especially those of her children. She said she’s going to stay in the program for a long time.

loans.use: To buy food and supplies for her fast food stall

loans.name: Sautaua

texts.en:
Sautaua is a lady of 42 years and is married with two children. She has been running her business for four years and is doing well.

She applied for this loan to buy materials and a new hand sewing machine to replace her old one.

Most of her clients come over to her place and give her their clothes to sew, but if it's slow, then she sews and sells at the flea markets.

She is aiming to buy an industrial sewing machine to make her work easier and quicker. That purchase will come from her next loan when she is finished paying her current loan. She also is planning to add an elei (a traditional Samoa fabric) business, because she’s good at it, and it goes together with her sewing business.

loans.use: To buy materials and tools for her sewing business

loans.name: Siimoa

texts.en:
Siimoa is married with four children, and she’s 46 years old. She is a very strong lady who works very hard in her plantation business. She plants different things, such as taro, taamu, bananas and yams.

She applied for this loan in order to buy chemicals and fertilizer to kill weeds and improve growth of the plantation. She also bought knives and other tools for planting.

She sells her produce at the market every weekday, where she makes $92 USD ($230 WST) per day. Her business is very helpful to the family in paying for their needs and especially sending her kids to school. That’s why she works very hard in her business.

loans.use: To buy tools and chemicals for her plantation

loans.name: Faasagaone

texts.en: Faasagaone is a 32 year old lady and is married with two kids. She applied for this loan in order to buy new fishing gear, such as the spears, goggles, fishing nets and a new canoe, for her husband. The rest of the loan was used to buy metal iron roofing material, cement, and timbers for repairing the roof and the old floor of her house. Her husband is a very good fisherman and he’s the one who work at the business while she provides financial help through her loans. She sells strings of fish around the village  three days per week and makes a profit of $140ST($56USD) per day but more at the Sunday morning fish market. Her business is growing very well and is very helpful to the family needs.

loans.use: To buy new fishing gear and for home improvement

loans.name: Malama

texts.en: Malama is a lady of forty five years of age and is married with seven children. She’s been in this business for more than five years now and this is the only source of income that supports her family needs and her kids' school fees. She applied for this loan in order to buy chemicals which helps in the plantation growth, and for tools needed in the working of the business. She sells her plantation goods such as taro, taamu, bananas, yams and vegetables at the market every week and she earns a profit of $180ST ($72USD) per day from selling two days a week.

loans.use: To buy tools and chemicals for her plantation

loans.name: Salome

texts.en: Salome is married with ten children and she’s 44 years old. She decided to create this business because she lives near the sea and thinks this is one of the good and profitable business in Samoa because this is an area where many tourists come to have fun. She applied for this loan in order to buy tools needed for making Samoan fales (open huts) for tourists and for beach decorations. She gets more than ten tourists per week and she usually makes $300ST ($120USD) per week and earns more during Christmas and New Years' time. She is very happy with her business because not only does she get money from  it, but also the opportunity to meet tourists and tell them about the Samoan culture. She hopes her next loan will help her improve her business and make the fales and beach decorations look nice.

loans.use: To buy tools for building Samoan fales and beach decorations

loans.name: Aisi

texts.en: Aisi T. is a new member to the loan program. Her business is selling popcorn. She sells five days a week and she sells at the school compound. She earns about 80-100 Tala ($32-40 US) a day and manages to make 500 Tala ($200 US) a week. She has no husband and one child who attends school. This is her first loan and this will be used for improving her existing business.

loans.use: Buy an oven, big pots, plastic papers, and ingredients for her popcorn business

loans.name: Uesa

texts.en: Uesa is on her second loan cycle. She grows taro, taamu and bananas on her plantation. Her husband is the one who really helps her with the work. She and her husband work on the plantation six days of the week, and on Fridays and Saturdays she has to go to the market to sell her stuff. She sells about twenty five taro for $20 WST ($8 USD), and she can manage to bring about $150-$200 WST ($60-80 USD) a day. Her gross sale for the week is $400-$500 WST ($160-200 USD) a week. She wants to continue in the future and she is aiming to extend her business.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Faatamalii

texts.en: Faatamalii is a fouty five year old lady who is married and has children. Her husband is an engineer and he runs his own taxi business. They have three children and one of them is staying in New Zealand and the other two are going to school. This is Faatamalii’s first loan and she is happy running her own business. She sells her goods from the front of her house and her customers are the traffic passers, the general public, and the village people. She is looking forward to earning more and expanding the business in the future.

loans.use: To buy boxes of turkey tails, mutton flaps, chicken legs, and tomato sauce for her barbecue business

loans.name: Viiga

texts.en: Viiga F. is a young mother of two loving children. Viiga was working as an employee of Samoa for years but now she is managing and running her own small business at home. This is her second loan and it has also the second year since she started the business. Viiga is staying with her mother and father. They are living together in one house and she and her husband are looking after the whole family. Viiga’s husband is working in the National Provident Fund, and he is really helping her out to sustain and run the business. The shop is in a good location near the School Compound and it has  grown a lot in the last two years. She is looking forward to expanding the business and she is also looking for more loans to maintain the business.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Olevia

texts.en: Olevia is one of the new members of the programme. Olevia prefers to run her popcorn business because her house is next to the school compound and she thinks this is a good location to earn money for her and her family. She is young and very active and she is planning to sell her goods five days a week and earn $80 a day. Her husband is a bus driver and he will help her with the payments in times of bad weather and school breaks.

loans.use: To buy plastic bags, a kerosene oven and other supplies for her popcorn business.

loans.name: Vaiauau

texts.en: Vaiauau is the eldest member of the Fata B Center and also the oldest member of the Center in the Programme. After four loans, she is still running and sustaining her sewing business and she is looking at improving her house  with this fifth loan. Her husband died years ago and she is still fighting with keeping up with everything in the family. Some of her children went overseas and she is not relying financially on them. She works everyday on catching up on her orders and earns $100 WST ($40 USD) a day. She is one of the oldest and most supportive members of her borrowing center.

loans.use: To buy fabrics, a new sewing machine, and other supplies for her sewing business

loans.name: Sikola

texts.en: Sikola is one of the oldest members of South Pacific Business Development and this is her first loan. Her two sons and husband are helping her operate her fishing business. She goes to the market three days a week and manages to bring around $400 WST ($160 USD) home during that time. The fishing is done six days a week, depending on the weather, and they prefer fishing at night because they catch more than in the daytime. She is very happy about running and sustaining her fishing business and she is always looking for more opportunities and markets for her products.

loans.use: To buy new fishing nets, hooks, and a new fishing boat

loans.name: Tautala

texts.en: Tautala is a thirty eight year old mother of four children. Tautala is still responsible of taking care of her two independents and she is making sure that the business is good to support them not only physically but also mentally in schooling. This is her fourth loan and she also intends to spend money on improving the plantation. She goes to the market two days a week and she can earn $400 WST ($160 USD) during that time period. She is thankful for the opportunity to be involved in the programme and to have these loans to help run their businesses.

loans.use: To buy chemicals for her plantation and iron roofing for home improvement

loans.name: Poto

texts.en: Poto joined the loan program in the 2004. She is a widowed lady and she has eight children. Her two sons work in the plantation and she is the one who is in charge of the costs and expenses of running the whole thing. Poto is one of the oldest members in the center and she is still active not only are her payments on time, but her business is running well.

loans.use: To buy chemicals, weed killer, tools and other supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Kaiva

texts.en: Kaiva is a mother from the village of Sologa Mulifanua. This is her fifth loan and she is one of the oldest members of the loan program. She has eight children and all of them are attending school except for one son who is working. Kaiva lives in the far west of Upolu but she go all the way to the town to sell her bags of taro, taamu, bananas, and yams. Kaiva’s husband does not work and there is no regular income for the family except the money they get from their plantation. There are six working days of the business and on Wednesdays and Fridays, Kaiva goes to the market to sell her stuff. This is Kaiva’s first business when she first joined SPBD and she is still maintaining it. She is one of the hardest working ladies and she is looking forward to obtain more loans from SPBD.

loans.use: To buy chemicals, bush knives, and a wheel barrow for her plantation

loans.name: Moe

texts.en: Moe T. is a new member of the loan program. She heard about SPBD a long time ago, and she wanted be able to run her own business. Moe sells her pancakes at the school compound and sells only five days of the week. She is now starting with a pancake business and if it goes well then she will add another one as a substitute. Moe’s husband works and this money will help her a lot. She has five children and she is working hard to support them not only physically, but also in schooling.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour, oil, an oven, and other ingredients for making pancakes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase his stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy spares and increase on pepper stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase his stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase his stock.

loans.name: Zephirine

texts.en:
Zephirine Tapé sells aluminum pots in the market of Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west coast of Cote d'Ivoire. She is 32 years old and has 2 children. She lives with her cohabitant and their children in Sassandra. Her cohabitant is a farm worker on cocoa plantations in the Sassandra region. Zephirine purchases aluminum pots from a blacksmith in a small village near Sassandra. The pots are used for cooking and they are deemed energy-saving.
