Zephirine is courageous and ambitious and she contributes significantly to her family's household and education expenses. She joined AE&I microcredit in April 2006 and has been a good performer ever since.

loans.use: to purchase aluminum pots from a blacksmith for re-sale

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine A. lives with her cohabitant and their 3 children in Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west coast of Cote d'Ivoire. She is 37 years old and has been selling fruits and vegetables in Sassandra's market for years.

Christine purchases her goods from various villages around Sassandra. She uses her income from the market stall to care for her family and pay education expenses.

Christine is an active member of the cooperative of tradeswomen of Sassandra. She will use the loan to purchase goods in bulk to improve her profit margin.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables for resale in her market stall

loans.name: Fofana

texts.en:
Fofana S. lives with her cohabitant and their 4 children in Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west coast of Cote d'Ivoire. She is 42 years old and sells various plastic utensils in the Sassandra market.

Ms. S.'s cohabitant is a fisherman. Except their elder son who is also a fisherman, all Ms. S.'s children go to school and she says that she will do her best to let her kids have access to university as well. She says that she regrets not having been able to pursue her own education as she was forced to stop at the end of elementary school because her parents were not able to pay her education expenses.

Ms. S. has been in our microcredit program for 3 years and she performs very well.

loans.use: to purchase goods for re-sale in her market stall

loans.name: Leontine

texts.en:
Leontine G. is a 48-year-old single mother. She has 3 children she has cared for alone for years. She lives with her children in Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west coast of Cote d'Ivoire.

Leontine sells various personal care and cosmetic products in the Sassandra market. She works with her elder daughter who travels to our neighoring country Ghana to purchase the goods her mother sells.

Leontine uses the income from her sales to pay household and education expenses for her younger children. She will use this loan to purchase goods in bulk to improve her profit margin.

loans.use: to purchase goods in bulk for re-sale in the market

loans.name: Amoin

texts.en:
Amoin K. sells vegetables. She is 34 years old, married, and has 2 children. She lives with her family in Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west coast of Cote d'Ivoire. She has been in the fruit and vegetable selling business since she was 17.

Amoin sells eggplant, okra, and tomatoes in the Sassandra market and contributes in that way to the household and education expenses of her family. Her husband is a factory worker in San-Pedro, near Sassandra. She is dynamic and a hard worker.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables to sell in the market

loans.name: Akoua

texts.en:
Akoua K. is a 34-year-old single mother. She has one child and lives in Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west Atlantic coast of Cote d'Ivoire. She has a little restaurant in Sassandra market where she sells various local foods especially "Attieke and fish," that is, cassava couscous and grilled fish. Her main customers are factory workers and tradesmen and tradeswomen operating stands in the market.

Akoua's foods are much appreciated. She uses the income from her little restaurant to support herself and her daughter. Akoua wants this loan to purchase various ingredients and fish for her restaurant.

loans.use: to purchase fish and other ingredients for the cooked food she sells

loans.name: Marie Louise

texts.en:
Marie Louise O. is a 32-year-old, dynamic woman. She lives with her cohabitant and their two children in Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west Atlantic coast of Cote d'Ivoire. Ms. O. has been selling vegetables such as onions, eggplant, okra, and tomatoes in the Sassandra market for years. She is a member of the cooperative of tradeswoman of Sassandra.

Ms. O. significantly contributes to household expenses and is proud to have been able to send her 2 children to school. Her cohabitant is a truck driver. Ms. O. has been in AE&I microcredit program since 2005 and has been a good performer.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables for re-sale at the market

loans.name: Usnamah

texts.en: Usnamah is 39-year-old woman who has a small shop which sells snacks, and household items. She usually earns US$5 per day with a small profit. Her husband, I., has no fixed income.  Usnamah needs a loan to buy more goods for her shop. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her shop

loans.name: Monassa

texts.en:
Monassa K. sells various fruits and vegetables. She is 36 years old and lives with her cohabitant and their 3 children in Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west coast of Cote d'Ivoire.

Monassa purchases goods in bulk from different villages in the Sassandra region and she then retails them at the Sassandra market in Abidjan. She is dynamic and well organized. She has been in the AE&I microcredit program since 2005 and has performed very well.

loans.use: to purchase goods in bulk for re-sale at her fruit and vegetable stand

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is 34-year-old woman who has a small shop which sells snacks, household goods, cigarettes, and many other things. She can earn US$44.50 per month, due to the amount and variety of goods she has in stock. Mariam requests a loan to buy more inventory for her shop. Her husband, J., has no regular  income, so she has to work very hard for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her shop

loans.name: Epah

texts.en: Epah is 26-year-old woman who has a small food stall which sells snacks, candies, flavoured ice sticks, etc., and  usually earns US$5.50 per day. Her husband, A., has no fixed income. Epah requests a loan to expand her business. She is a member and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette S. E., 52, is a widow. She lives in Sassandra, a rural town on the south-west coast of Cote d'Ivoire and sells used clothes in Sassandra market. Jeannette lives alone as all her 3 children have left Sassandra and live in other towns. She runs this business to provide for herself and pay for her daily needs.

Jeannette has been in the AE&I microcredit program for 2 years and has performed very well. She is well-organized and attentive to detail in running her business.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes to re-sell in the market

loans.name: Ami

texts.en: Ami is 34-year-old woman who has a small shop where she sells snacks, household goods, cigarettes, beverages and many other things. She can earn US$44.50 per month, due to the amount and variety of goods she has in stock. Ami requests a  loan to fill her shop with more inventory. Her husband, S., has no regular income, so she has to work hard for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To fill her shop with more inventory

loans.name: Mimi

texts.en: Mimi is a 36-year-old woman who sells snacks, drinks, candies and household goods at her small shop and usually earns US$10 per day. Her husband, K., has no regular income. Mimi requests a loan to expand her business, so she could earn extra income for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Jesse

texts.en: Jesse F. is from the village of Samatau. This is one of the oldest and most active centres of the loan program. She is applying for this loan in order to improve her business and also for the improvement of her house. Jesse delivers her biscuits to the urban retail shops five days of the week and makes 300 WST ($120 USD) a week. She has no husband or children, and she is responsible for taking care of her elderly grandmother and grandfather. She is one of the active members of the loan program, and she is looking forward to receiving more loans.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour, sugar, and other ingredients for her Samoan biscuits business

loans.name: Mataitusi

texts.en: Mataitusi is one of the older members of the programme. Mataitusi sells five days of the week at the village primary school. She also weaves fine mats and sells them at the Fugalei Market. These fine mats are needed by people during special events like funerals and weddings. Mataitusi is in her fifties, and she is still active and hard-working. She is still sustaining her pancake business as well as her fine mats business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for pancakes and also for house improvement

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Naomi F. is a married lady with four kids. All the children are attending the village primary school, and she is working hard to support them. Her husband is a farmer, and he also sells taro and bananas at the market two days of the week. Naomi prefer to sells her popcorn at the village primary school. During the school breaks and holidays, she will rely on the money from the plantation for the loan payment and also for the family expenses.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her bakery and popcorn businesses

loans.name: Velonika

texts.en: Velonika is from the village of Vaiusu. Velonika is on her fifth loan, and she is planning to use this loan on her lawn mowing business. Velonika’s husband does not work, and this is their only source of income. They work only when requested, and they also have temporary orders for the week. The money they get depends on the size of the area where they work. Velonika is one of our most reliable members. She is hard-working and active.

loans.use: To buy a new lawn mower

loans.name: Tuaoitaua

texts.en: Tuaoitaua is from the village of Faleula. Tuaoitaua was attending the USP (University of the South Pacific) at Alafua, studying this area of planting and arranging flowers. This is her first loan from SBPD, and she is using this loan to upgrade her facilities to make sure that the work is carried out efficiency and productively. Tuaoitaua had been doing this business for years before she heard about SPBD loans. She is so grateful to be part of this program, and she is looking forward to continuing to earn income for more expansion and further improvement.

loans.use: To buy pots, black plastic bags, and tools for her florist business

loans.name: Imeleta

texts.en: Imeleta S. is married and has children. She is from the village of Sinamoga, and her business is selling barbeque plates. She works three days only, and she sells one barbeque plate for 6 tala ($2.40 USD). Imeleta also supplies pies for birthdays and special events. These pies are only made when customers phone in the orders. This is her second loan, and she will use this loan to buy stuff for her barbeque. She is one of SPBD's active members and she is doing well with her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour and boxes of mutton flaps and turkey tails for her barbecue business

loans.name: Tinoai Sefo

texts.en: Tinoai is one of the eldest mothers within the loan program, but she is still active in doing her business. This is her fifth loan, and she is using this loan to improve her flower garden in her front yard. Tinoai likes flowers, and this is why she has decided to use this loan on her flower garden. Not only she is talented in planting flowers, she is also good at weaving fine mats. These fine mats are much needed by families during special events such as funerals, weddings and birthdays. These are her two major skills, and she is doing both activities at the same time. Tinoai is one of the supportive members of the center, and she is doing well with her business as well as the payments.

loans.use: To buy pots, fertilizers, tools, and equipment for her flower garden.

loans.name: Toaga

texts.en: Toaga E. comes from the village of Saoluafata. She is on her fourth loan and her business is the plantation. She grows taro, bananas and taamu. Her husband is unemployed and helps out by doing the manual labor. Instead of going to the market, which is more expensive, she prefers to sell her produce in front of the village store. She sells five days of the week and can earn $80 WST ($32 USD) a day, and about $400 WST ($160 USD) a week. She is looking forward to receiving more loans from SPBD. She says these loans are very supportive not only to the family, but especially for the children in school.

loans.use: To buy knives, an ax, weed killer, and a wheel barrow for her plantation

loans.name: Tipesa

texts.en: Tipesa is the chief of the Satapuala borrowing center. Tipesa has being running her shop for more than three years, and this is the first time she is borrowing money for the business. Tipesa's shop is located at the front of the house. It is open from six o’clock in the morning until nine in the evening. The shop is owned by her daughter but when she moved to New Zealand, Tipesa took over. Tipesa’s shop is open six days a week, and she can manage to earn $150 WST ($60 USD) a day. She is still active and doing well in running her business.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Soliga

texts.en: Soliga M. is one of the new members of the loan programme. This is her first loan and also her first time ever to borrow money from an organization. As a guarantee when she applied for loans, she told the banks that she has being running her plantation for years, but the banks wouldn't accept her guarantee. This time she is so happy to be one of those ladies who borrow money from SPBD and will pay back later. Soliga is selling taro, taamu, bananas, and yams from her plantation, and she sells them at the Fugalei Market. She is honest and a hard-working lady.

loans.use: To buy chemicals, equipment, and a wheelbarrow for her plantation business

loans.name: Tupaolo

texts.en: Tupaolo is from Sauano Fagaloa. She is 34 years old, married, and has children. Tupaolo’s husband does not have a good educational background and, therefore, does not have a good job. Since Tupaolo joined the programme, her husband has been helping her out with carving and designing handicrafts. The couple then sells the handicrafts to flea market owners and to hotels for tourists from overseas. Tupaolo is a hard-working lady and is looking forward to continuing earning income with the help of SPBD. She is one of the oldest members of the programme, and this is her second loan. She would like to borrow US$475 to buy a new filing machine and tools for her business.

loans.use: Purchase of a new filing machine and tools for a handicrafts business

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina L. is from the village of Falefa. She runs a plantation business, and it is going well. Sina’s husband does not work, and he is the right hand of Sina in running the business. The couple sells taro and banana at the Fugalei Market two days a week. Sina is very hard working and one of the most reliable members of the programme. She is also one of its oldest members, and this is her sixth loan since she joined SPBD. Sina needs to borrow US$300 to buy chemicals, knives, and other supplies for the plantation.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals, knives, and other supplies for a plantation

loans.name: Suluama

texts.en: Suluama is from the village of Falefa. She is married and has three children. They are all very young and depend on Suluama's support. Her husband works, and his income helps in covering basic payments and other family expenses. Suluama is young and talented, and her main source of income is a plantation business. It is the fifth time that Suluama is borrowing money - she will use the US$800 to purchase knives, chemicals and tools for her plantation, hoping that it will allow her to earn more income in the future and let her better support her children in school.

loans.use: Purchase of bush knives, chemicals and tools for a plantation

loans.name: Kalala

texts.en: Kalala L. is from the Village of Falelauniu. She sells chips five days a week at a primary school, and manages to earn about $150 WST (US$60) a day. Kalala is one of the oldest members of the programme, and it is the fifth time she is borrowing from it. She plans to use to current loan money to improve her chips business by purchasing more bananas and plastic bags. Kalala's business so far has been going well, and she has been successful in repaying the previous loans.

loans.use: Purchase of plastic bags and bananas for a chips business

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina K. is 38 years old, a mother, and lives in the village of Faleula. She has five children, all of whom are young and dependent on her. She owns a lawn-mowing business, which has been going well. Currently, Sina is asking for her fifth loan, which she will use to buy a second-hand lawn mower to replace her old one. She is one of the hardest working members of the loan program.

loans.use: Purchase of a new lawn mower

loans.name: Tapuni

texts.en: Tapuni is from the village of Satapuala. She runs a pancake business - she sells pancakes at a village primary school and to the village people six days a week. Tapuni usually makes about $300 WST (US$120) a week. She is doing well with the payment of her first loan, and is working hard to be able to borrow from SPBD again in the future. Tapuni is one of the oldest members of the loan program, and is currently asking for her second loan which will be used to buy bags of flour, sugar, and a fryer for her business.

loans.use: Purchase of bags of flour, sugar and a fryer for a pancake business

loans.name: Faalua

texts.en: Faalua is the secretary of Solaua Center. She is 28 years old and runs a plantation and an ice cake business. She sells her ice cakes (popsicles in a bag) for fifty sene (20 cents) each at a Primary School Compound, and her plantation produce to the Fugalei Market. She has three children, and they are all young and dependent on her. Faalua's husband works as a carpenter, earning additional income for the family. Faalua is hard-working, reliable and supportive, and needs to borrow money to buy plastic bags and a second-hand refrigerator to improve her ice cake business.

loans.use: Purchase of plastic bags, and a second-hand refrigerator for her ice cake business

loans.name: Tania

texts.en: Tania is 25 years old, a mother, and lives in the village of Vailoa Tai. She has two children who are attending primary school, and Tania is completely responsible for taking care of them. She runs a sewing business at her own home in Vailoa Tai, while her husband is a carpenter. This is Tania's fourth loan, and she will use it to improve her sewing business. She is very active and is looking forward to borrowing from the program again in the future to continue running her business and to support her children in school.

loans.use: Purchase of materials, needles and a new sewing machine for a sewing business

loans.name: Vavao

texts.en: Vavao F. is 42 years old, married, and has five children. She is from the village of Falelauniu and has only recently joined the loan program. Vavao does not have good education, but is talented in growing various vegetables. She works on the vegetable garden almost all the time, every day of the week. Vavao grows cabbages, cucumbers and tomatoes, as well as runs a taro plantation and banana plantation. This is Vavao’s main source of income. Her husband also works, earning about $150 WST (US$60) a week. He goes to work five days a week and spends the weekends at the plantation. Vavao is borrowing for the first time and is looking forward to improving her business.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers, seeds, chemicals, a spade, a crowbar, and other supplies for a plantation

loans.name: Sisi

texts.en: Sisi is a nineteen year-old lady from the village of Sagafili Mulifanua. She is running a small business and she sells bags of popcorn at the village primary school. The school is open five days of the week and therefore she sells five days only. Sisi prefers to sell her stuff at the school compound which she thinks is a better market than anywhere else. Sisi finished school last year and then she stayed home to look after her parents. She wanted something to do and when she heard about the SPBD loan program, she thought that this would be a good help for her and the family. She is waiting for her first loan and this money will be used to buy bags, a gas oven and ingredients for the pop corn business. She is an active member and she is making a good start already.

loans.use: To buy an oven, gas, pots and ingredients for her popcorn business

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia is twenty-two years of age and she is from the village of Vailoa Tai. She is one of the newest members and this is her first loan. Patricia’s husband works at the Electrical Power Corporation and he earns fortnightly. She has three kids and all of them are in school. Patricia’s business is selling barbecue plate. She is planning to do her business at the front of her house and her customers are the locals, the passing traffic, and village people. She is young and active and she is looking forward to growing her business.

loans.use: To buy potatoes, soy sauce, onions, and boxes of mutton flaps, turkey tails and sausages for the barbecue business

loans.name: Sasani

texts.en: Sasani I. is a thirty-five year old lady from the village of Vailoa Tai. She has a second-hand refrigerator and she decided to run an ice cake business in order to have access to SPBD loans. Her husband does not work and there is no other source of income for her to support her family and the children. She has five kids and all of them are young and attending primary school. Sasani is using this loan on buying stuff for the ice cake and she is looking forward to selling it at school and also to the village people. There will be six working days and she is looking at earning about 50-80 WST ($20-32 USD) a week.

loans.use: To buy bags of sugar, flour, plastics bags, and ingredients for the ice cake business

loans.name: Pule

texts.en: Pule A. is one of the new members of the programme. She is from the village of Sagafili Mulifanua. She just joined last week and she is deciding to do a pig farm. She already has lots of pigs but she needs a sty for them. She is twenty-seven years of age and her husband works at the Le Vasa Hotel. She has two children, who both have physical and mental disabilities. She is planning to sell her pigs to the restaurants and also to the public for special events. This is Pule’s first loan and she is looking forward to more loans in the future.

loans.use: To buy wires, cement, and pipe tubes for her pig farm

loans.name: Nghor

texts.en: Mrs. Nghor S., 26, is a mother of one school-aged child and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She stays at home cooking food and her husband works at home operating a stand where he charges a variety of batteries for the people in his area. He earns on average around $7/day. In order to help her family generate more income, Mrs. Nghor S. would like to open a business selling sugar cane juice in her community. She is requesting a loan of $700 so she can purchase a machine used to produce sugar can juice, utensils, chairs, tables, and other items for her new business.

loans.use: To purchase a machine used to produce sugar can juice, utensils, chairs, tables and other items for a new business

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Nghor Sy has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Prach

texts.en: Mr. Prach S., age 30, earns $1 a day as a farmer.  His wife is employed at a garment factory and earns about $3 a day.  The couple supports their child and Mr. Prach S.’s elderly father with their jobs.  He is requesting a loan of $300 to to take advantage of bulk purchasing prices for seeds, as well as fertilizer to increase crop yields on his farm.  He plans to use the additional earnings generated from the loan to purchase pigs for resale and expand his farming operations.  With their increased income, the couple will fund their child’s education and continue support Mr. Prach S.’s father. His wife is pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer.

payments.comment: Thanks to the successful of Mr. Prach Sarenn’s business now he can pay off the loan ahead of time. The money he loaned from Kiva made his business goes forward. He would like to thank to the lenders.

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Mrs. Lun S., age 40, is a farmer who earns about $1 a day cultivating her land.  Her husband has a well-digging business and earns about $3 a day.  They have four children, two who are workers in a garment factory, one who is a laborer, and one who is a student.  She is requesting a loan for $1000 to purchase new tools for her husband’s business.  These tools will allow him to work more efficiently and provide higher quality service to his customers.  They will also use this loan to fix his car, allowing him to travel further for business.  They plan to use the increased income to help fund their child’s education and reinvest in her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for her husband's well-digging business.

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Mrs. Him S., age 38, is a wedding director and earns about $3.50 a day.  Her husband is a photographer, earning about $3.50 a day.  The couple has one child, who is a full-time student.  She is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase additional wedding clothes for her inventory, taking advantage of the big demand for wedding garments.  She plans to use additional income from the loan to help support her child’s education and expand her business in other ways.

loans.use: To purchase wedding clothes to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Pun

texts.en: Mrs. Pun S., age 25, runs a butchery and grocery store out of her home, earning about $5 each day in revenue.  Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning about $5 each day.  She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase additional inventory and build a stand for her business.  She hopes to take advantage of bulk discounts by purchasing large quantities of goods for her grocery operations, thus lowering inventory costs and increasing profitability.  She would like to use the additional earnings generated by this loan to expand her product range, build her business, and increase the family’s savings.

loans.use: To purchase an inventory of grocery goods and to build a grocery stand.

loans.name: Kert

texts.en: Mrs. Kert K., age 47, is a fruit vendor a local market, earning about $6 a day in revenue.  Her husband works as a farmer.  The couple has one child, who is a student.  She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase more fruits for her inventory.  She will take advantage of bulk discounts by purchasing large quantities of fruit for her inventory.  This will also help her meet consumers’ demand for different types of fruits by expanding her product range.  She plans to use the additional earnings generated by this loan to expand her business and help fund her child’s education.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Nghem

texts.en: Mrs. Nghem K., 47, is married and lives with her husband and nine children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work on a piece of land where they grow and grind rice crops, earning collectively around $4.50/day. Four of her children are employed at a garment factory located in Phnom Penh city, and the other five are enrolled in school. To expand her crops and make job further faster and easier Mrs. Nghem K. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more seeds and a grinding mill so that she won’t have t o grind her crops manually. This will increase her production, and thus her income.

loans.use: To purchase more rice crops and a grinding mill to faciltate her job.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Nghem Kheng has repaid this Kiva loan early!

Thanks to lenders like you, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to help them support their small businesses and families. We hope that you will continue investing in Kiva entrepreneurs.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana L. is a twenty year old lady from the village of Mulifanua. She is married and has no kids. Her husband does not work and she is relying on her mother for everything, especially for food and all that. She wants to start a business selling Keke Saina, a special Samoan food, so that she can help her mother with some of the expenses. The business will sell and deliver to the rural store and also to the village people and the public. This will be her first loan and she is looking forward to earning more loans in the future from SPBD.

loans.use: To buy bags of sugar, flour, oil, and pots for her Keke Saina business

loans.name: Tat

texts.en: Mrs. Tat P., age 40, manages a stand that sells rice, food, and soft drinks. She earns about $5. Her husband is a mechanic and earns about $5 a day.  The couple has three children, all of which are students.  She is requesting a loan of $1000 to expand product offerings at her stand and to purchase an air-pump machine for her husband’s business.  They believe this will lead to an increase in sales revenue at the wife’s stand, and increase the range of services offered by the husband’s business.  They plan to use the increased income to fund their children’s education. He husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to expand her store and an air-pump maching to help her husband's business.

loans.name: Fauu

texts.en: Faauu M. is a thirty-year-old mother from Salua Manono and her business is her family plantation. She grows taro, bananas, and taamu at the plantation and she goes to the market two days a week.  Her husband is working in New Zealand and the plantation is run by her father. Fauu’s father has private lands in the village and this is cultivated for the plantation. She has five children and the money from the plantation and the income from her husband are her two major source of income. She is one of the oldest members of the loan program and she is still active and honest with repayment. She is looking forward to earning more loans, and she is also looking at expanding the business in the future.

loans.use: To buy chemicals for the plantation and also iron roofing for home improvement

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika is a thirty-one-year-old mother from the village of Falefa. She is running a pop corn business and she is selling her product at the village primary school. Monika is on her first loan and she is using it to start the business. She has three kids who are attending the primary school and also takes care of her parents. She sells five days a week and is able to get about $80 WST ($32 USD) a day. She is confident that she will be successful in the future and that this business will be a solution to all her financial problems.

loans.use: To buy a new oven, some fryers, and ingredients for her popcorn and donuts business

loans.name: Masele

texts.en: Masele M. is a thirty-year-old lady from the village of Vailoa Tai. Her business is selling barbecue plates that contain chicken leg, turkey tail, and a mutton flap with salad on it. Masele can sell about thirty to fifty plates a day for 1 Tala (40 cents) a plate. She sells beside the road in front of her house, and she is targeting the passing traffic, the village people and employees within that area. Vailoa Tai is not too far from the town area and she thought that this would be the most profitable business for her to run. She has no husband, no children and the only thing she is looking at is taking care of her parents. This is her first loan and she is looking forward to earning more loans in the future for expansion of her business.

loans.use: To buy boxes of mutton flaps, turkey tail, chicken legs and all the ingredients for her barbecue business

loans.name: Um

texts.en: Mrs. Um Y., age 54, works selling foodstuffs and provisions, earning only $1/day of profit. Her husband, age 56, works as a farmer, making about $1 each day. They have seven children, two who are mechanics, two who are students, and three who are married and live separately. She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase piglets to raise and resell in the market for a profit. Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and resell in the market for a profit.

loans.name: Mulivai Ah

texts.en: Mulivai Ah P. is thirty-two years of age and is married with three kids. Her husband works as a carpenter and this is the only source of income for the family. Mulivai heard about SBPD loans and she thought that this would be the best opportunity for her to join in. Mulivai likes flowers and planting flower plants, and this is why she thought that this could be the way of putting her imagination into action. This is her first loan to start up the business and she said that she will make good use of this loan. She has three kids who are attending the village primary school, and she will make sure that these loans help them succeed in the future.

loans.use: To buy a spade, pots, plastic bags, wheel barrow, and a hoist for irrigation for her flower garden

loans.name: Gaga

texts.en: Gaga P. is one of the young mothers of the loan program from the village of Faleula. She is twenty-two years of age, and she has one loving son. Her husband does not work but he is a good fisherman who is talented on the sea. He goes fishing six days a week, depending on the weather. When her husband comes back successfully then Gaga is responsible for selling the fish. Depending on the quantity, she either goes to the market or sells at the roadside. She sells one string that contains about 25 fish for $20 WST ($8 USD), and usually she can sell about five to six strings of fish a day. She is one of the new members and she is young and very active.

loans.use: To buy strings, hooks, and some new sets of fishing nets for the fishing business

loans.name: Sulesa

texts.en:
Sulesa lives near the town area on the north side. She is from the village of Sinamoga and she is married with 3 lovely kids. Her husband does not have a good educational background but he is a good swimmer and a good fisherman. Sulesa is only twenty-five years of age and she is young and active.

She heard about SBPD loans weeks ago, and she decided to join so that her husband can have good fishing equipment for his fishing business, and the money left will be used for her barbecue business. Sulesa plans to run the barbecue business as an alternative income in time of bad weather. The barbecue will be sold in front of her house beside the roadside and it will cost $6 WST ($2.40 USD) for one plate. Sulesa is a happy lady now, and she is looking forward to earning more in the future.

loans.use: To buy boxes of mutton flaps, turkey tails, chicken legs and cucumbers for her barbecue business

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao F. is forty years of age from the village of Falelauniu. She is running a taro and banana plantation, and she sells at the Fugalei Market. Sao’s husband does not work and he is the one that is really helping Sao out with the plantation. She works six days a week and she sells three days at the market.

Sao said that this is the first time she has had access to loans and that she will make good use of this opportunity. This is her first loan and this is the beginning of her business life. She is very active and she is confident that she will be successful in the future.

loans.use: To buy knives, fertilizers, weed killer, and a hoist for the plantation

loans.name: Mekala

texts.en:
Mekala V. is forty years of age, from the village of Faleula. She has three young kids and they are attending primary school. Mekala‘s husband does not have a job and there in no regular income for her and the family.

When she heard about SBPD loans, she joined one of the centers at the village and tried to find out if she is qualifed. She is on her first loan now and she is using all of it on starting up the business. Mekala already has a big plantation and she is now turning it into a business. She is also running a vegetable garden business, and her dream is to be successful in the future.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds, chemicals and fertilizers for the plantation

loans.name: Seseei

texts.en:
Seseei is from the village of Faleula. She is forty-eight years of age and she has eleven children. She has no job and she is responsible for taking care of the kids. The husband also has no job and there in no regular income for her and the family.

This is a very good opportunity for her. This is the first time ever she is entitled to borrow money and she said that the opportunity should not be ignored. She is using her first loan to start up a pancake business. She is planning to sell at the primary school compound and she is targeting the school children as her core market. She is happy to run her own business and she is looking forward to continuing to earn more loans from SBPD.

loans.use: To buy bags of sugar, flour and oil for the pancake business

loans.name: Corina

texts.en:
Corina M. is forty-five years of age from the village of Faleula. She has five children and she was divorced a long time ago from her husband. She is responsible for all her children’s needs and wants, and also she is taking care of her old grandmother. This is her second loan, and she is sustaining her retail shop which is at the front of her house at Faleula.

She is using this loan on home improvement, and she is one of the good members in the programme. She is open seven days a week from 6.00am to 10.00pm and she manages to earn with about $180 WST ($72 USD) a day and about $1200 ($480 USD) a week. This is the only source of income she is relying on and she is grateful for the opportunity she gets to borrow more money for maintaining her business.

loans.use: To buy iron roofing for  house improvement

loans.name: Fiona

texts.en: Fiona H. is one of the newly active members of the loan program. She is from the village of Vaiusu and she is a good cook and a good tailor. She has seven kids and her husband is a good engineer. Fiona sells plates of different food at her church center. She joined at the beginning of this year and now she is asking for another loan before the end of the year. She is a hard-working lady and she is going full speed this time to make sure that  money from foreign tourists will come to her during this time of Christmas.

loans.use: To pay for the children's school fees, and for supplies for her sewing business and her food stall business

loans.name: Osana

texts.en:
Osana M. is a thirty-five year old lady from the village of Vaimoso Uta. She has six children and they are attending school. Osana’s only source of income before she joined the loan program was her husband’s salary as a bus driver. He drives six days a week and earns $250 WST ($100 USD). Osana's business is delivering packages for other people.

This is Osana’s second loan and she is spending it on iron roofing for her house. She is doing well with her business and she is looking forward to earn more loans from SBPD in the future.

loans.use: To buy iron roofing for home improvement

loans.name: Litara

texts.en:
Litara U. is fifty-four years of age from the village of Vaiusu. She is the Secretary of the Center and she is one of the reliable members of the programme. Litara is growing old and not suited to hard jobs. She has working children but she never relies on them for her needs and wants.

Litara noticed that most of the women in her area go to other villages to play bingo. She organizes bingo on Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday nights and she manages to bring around 500 Tala ($200 USD) per night. She is very happy to run her business and she is looking forward to earning more loans from SPBD.

loans.use: To buy iron roofing for house improvement

loans.name: Taele

texts.en: Taele was one of the first participants in our loan program. She is 38 years old and has four children. Taele comes from the village of Manono, where she runs a plantation on which she grows taro, taamu and bananas -- the three most popular crops in Samoa. Taele’s husband works elsewhere during the week, but on weekends they work the plantation together. Taele goes to market to sell her crop each Friday and Saturday, and can make $48 a day selling her produce.  She has applied for a new loan to expand and upgrade her business, and looks forward to continuing to be active in our program.

loans.use: To buy chemicals, knives, a wheelbarrow and weed killer for her plantation

loans.name: Ma

texts.en: Mrs. Ma N., age 49, is a widow who works selling rice and various kinds of Khmer food, earning about $6 per day. She has six children. Two are employed at a garment factory, earning about $70-80 per month each, one is a student, and three are married and live separately. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase more inventory and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of rice and Khmer food.

loans.name: Ma

texts.en: Mrs. Ma N., age 49, is a widow who works selling rice and various kinds of Khmer food, earning about $6 per day. She has six children, two who are employed at a garment factory, earning about $70-80 per month each, one who is a student, and three who are married and live separately. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase more inventory and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of rice and Khmer food.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Mrs. Kim L., age 55, is a widow who works selling grocery products, making about $4.80 each day. She has one child who is a chef, earning about $2.40 per day. She is requesting a loan of $600 in order to purchase more grocery items to expand her inventory to fulfill her client’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to expand her inventory to fulfill her client’s needs.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Mrs. Kim L., age 55, is a widow who works selling grocery products, making about $4.80 each day. She has one child who is a chef, earning about $2.40 per day. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase more grocery items to expand her inventory to fulfill her client’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to expand her inventory to fulfill her client’s needs.

loans.name: Sera

texts.en: Sera F. lives in the village of Sinamoga, where she runs a barbecue business. She is 27 years old and has one son. She sells her goods three days a week , and usually earns about $160 a month. Sera has received two loans from us, and made good use of each of them to run and expand her business. She is a hard-working woman, and has come to us for a new loan to buy more food to cook and sell at her barbecue stand.

loans.use: To buy items to barbecue, such as mutton, turkey and sausage

loans.name: Teleofa

texts.en: Teleofa lives in the village of Samatau, where she runs a plantation. She is a very hard-working woman, and one of the best clients we have at the Samatau Center. Teleofa works on her plantation six days a week, taking time off only to bring her goods to market. She is 38 years old and supports several children, all of whom are in school. Her husband works at a nearby hotel, and his income used to be the family's sole means of support before Teleofa secured her first loan, which allowed her to start her own business. Now she has applied for a new loan to improve her plantation. She is grateful for the support she has received, and looks forward to more activity with SPBD in the future.

loans.use: To buy chemicals for her plantation

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en: Mrs. Ouk S., age 35, works raising pigs to sell at the market. Her husband works buying and selling recyclable items, earning about $0.30 per day. They have three children, two who are too young to attend school, and one who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase more pigs, build a barn, and purchase feeds to supplement her livestock. Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase mroe pugs, build a barn, and purchase livestock feed.

loans.name: Caroline Ah

texts.en:
Caroline Ah P. was one of the first clients of our loan program, but has been out of work for the last few months because of an injury to her arm. She has three children, all of whom are in school. Her husband is an excellent and very popular carpenter, and has been the family's sole means of support since Caroline's injury.

Now that she has recovered, Caroline has applied for a loan to start an elei (a traditional Samoan fabric) printing business. She will work on her elei for six days a week and take her goods to market each Saturday, where she will sell them to people who own retail shops and have stalls in the local flea market. Caroline is excited to be doing this, now that she has recovered from her illness and making a new start.

loans.use: To buy materials for her elei printing business

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Mrs. Hem S. M., age 30, is a vendor selling fruits, earning around $1.60 each day of profit. Her husband is a pharmacist, earning about $9 each day in revenue. They have four children, three who are too young to attend school and one who is a student. Hem would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase more medical supplies and fruits for their inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more medical supplies and fruits for their inventory.

loans.name: Khim

texts.en: Mrs. Khim K. T., age 52, works raising and selling pigs at the market. Her husband works his land growing crops, earning around $2.60 each day. They have five children, some who are employed at a garment factory and some who are married. Khim would like to request a loan of $400 in order to purchase more pigs to expand her business to generate additional profit.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to raise.

loans.name: Va

texts.en: Mrs. Va K. S., age 68, is a widow who works with her one daughter on a plot of land growing crops and raising pigs, Together they earn around $7 each day. Va would like to request a loan of $700 in order to purchase seeds and pigs to expand her livestock and generate additional income.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and pigs to expand her livestock and generate additional income

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Mrs. Vorn P.,age 48, works as a farmer. Her husband is a carpenter making tables, cabinets, and other furniture, earning around $5 each day. They have eight children, four who are employed at a garment factory, one who is a laborer in Korea, and three who are students. Vorn would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a motorbike to use for her family’s transportation. This will allow her children to get to work more efficiently as well, therefore increasing their productivity.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to use for her family’s transportation.

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mrs. Cheng C., age 41, is a vendor selling foodstuffs and provisions from her home, earning around $2 each day. Her husband is a policeman, making $1 each day. They have four children, two who work as security guards and two who are students. Cheng would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to go to work. She can also use the bike to purchase supplies for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to get to work.

payments.comment:
Congratulation to Mrs. Sek Mey!!!!!!!!

Now She is able to pay off her loan very early. On behalf of Mrs Sek Mey, we would like to say greatly thank to all the lenders who always support and help to our poor entrepreneurs. your loan can make different. 

we will provide the Journal update of Sek Mey family as soon as we could so that you will understand what different your loan make on her and her family. 

Many Thanks again

loans.name: Krouch

texts.en: Mrs. Krouch Y., age 41, works with her husband selling fish in their community, making around $4 each day of profit together. They have two children who are unemployed. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a motor-bike for her husband to drive a motor-taxi which would enable him to generate more income for his family.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike for her husband to drive a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im S., age 55, is a widow and works selling porridge, earning around $1 each day. She has two children, one who is employed at a garment factory earning $80 per month, and one works growing cashew nut trees. Her granddaughter also lives with her and works in a factory earning around $80 per month. Im would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a plot of land to help her son grow cashew nut trees.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to help her son grow cashew nut trees.

loans.name: Houn

texts.en: Mrs. Houn K. H., age 49, is a farmer, earning $1 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman, making about $6 each day. They have three children, one who is employed at a garment factory and two who are students. Houn would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a wood house frame and some construction tools for her husband's job. This will expand his business and increase their family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase construction supplies.

loans.name: Yem

texts.en: Mrs. Yem L., age 45, works with her husband selling fish, making around $4 per day. They have six children, one who is employed in a garment factory earning $80 per month, three are students, and two who are married and live away from home. Yem would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a motor-bike and a trailer to run a business transporting passengers. This will increase her family’s income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike and a trailer to run a business transporting passengers.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en: Mrs. Sen S., 51, is a widow who lives with her two children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. To supplement her entire family, she and one of her sons work on a plot of land growing rice crops, earning together around $1.50 each day. Her other son works as a blacksmith. Mrs. Sen S. hopes to use this loan to purchase some blacksmith’s tools and metals for her son to expand his business. This is a second loan for Sen S. after her first loan was successfully repaid.

loans.use: To purchase some blacksmith’s tools and metals for her son to expand his business.

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Mrs. Nov N., age 40, works with her husband selling sugar cane juice and some grocery products, earning around $3.60 each day. They have two children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase an ice cream cart and more grocery products to expand their business and increase their family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase an ice cream cart and more grocery products.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mrs. Kong N., age 38, is a farmer, earning around $2.50 each day. Her husband is a fisherman, making $2.90 /day. They have five children, three who are students and two who are married and live away from home. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase more ducklings to raise and sell in the market to generate additional income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase ducklings to raise.

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Mrs. Him C. and her husband are traditional doctors together earning around $10 each day. They have five children, two who are employed at a casino, making about $100 per month each, one who is a part-time traditional doctor earning about $100 per month, and one who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $1200 in order to purchase pigs to breed and sell for additional income.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to breed and sell for additional income.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly S., age 47, is a widow who owns a mini-van transportation business, earning around $7.20 each day. She has four children, two who are married and live separately, and two who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1200 in order to purchase yams from the growers and resell in the market for a good profit.

loans.use: To purchase yams from the growers and resell in the market for a good profit.

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Mrs Chin P., age 38, works with her husband as a laborer, making together on average about $5 per day. They have three children, two who are laborers and one who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase yams from the growers to resell for a profit to help improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase yams from the growers to resell for a profit.

loans.name: Seam

texts.en: Mrs. Seam H., 19,  is married with one little child and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She works as a masseuse, earning around $5/day in revenue. Mrs. Seam H. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business so that her family’s income generation will be steadily increased. (Her Husband is pictured with a motor-bike he plans to use for his business because Mrs. Seam H. was unavailable)

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business.

loans.name: Chhoin

texts.en: Mrs. Chhoin S., age 26, works as a traditional doctor, making $5 per day. Her husband is a blacksmith, earning about $8/day. They have three children who are too young to attend school. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase more metals and medicines to expand both of their businesses and meet customer demand.

loans.use: To purchase more metals and medicines to expand both of their businesses.

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Mrs. Neang K., age 49, is widow who works at a garment factory, earning about $4 each day. She has three children who are employed at a garment factory as well. She also takes care of her mother who lives with her. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a motorcycle for her family’s transportation. This will make it easier for her and her children to get to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her family’s transportation.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Neang Khoin has paid back this Kiva loan early.

Thank your for your support. Thanks to lenders like you, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to invest into their small businesses and families. We hope that you will continue your support  and reinvest your loan in another entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Mrs. Long S., age 25, is a garment worker, making around $2 per day. Her husband is a laborer, making about $2.50 each day. Her child is too young to attend school. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi, which will enable him to generate much more income than working as a laborer. This will help improve their family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to operate a motor-taxi business.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Long Sochea and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Kung

texts.en: Mrs. Kung Ann, age 37, works selling vegetables, making around $5 each day of profit. Her husband works on a piece of farmland growing crops and raising pigs, earning about $2.50 per day. They have four children who are students. She would like to request a loA. of $700 in order to purchase a hand-tractor to assist in plowing their farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a hand-tractor to assist in plowing her farmland.

loans.name: Ek

texts.en: Mrs. Ek V., age 41, is a housewife. Her husband, age  47, works as a farmer, climbing palm trees to collect the sap that produces palm sugar.He earns around $2.40 each day. They have six children, five who are employed at a garment factory and one who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to purchase  bamboo to use as a ladder and to repair her house to shelter her family.

loans.use: To purchase bamboo to use as a ladder and to repair her house.

loans.name: Savali

texts.en: Savli is 39 years old and lives in the village of Leusoalii, where she runs a business selling bananas and taro at the town market every Friday.  She has two children, both of whom are in school.  Her banana and taro plantation has done well, and is the sole means of support for her family. Sales generate a profit of $80 a day, which Savli uses to pay the bills, run her business and make donations to her church. She plans to use this new loan (her second)  to expand her business and help renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy supplies and tools for her banana plantation

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Mrs. Meas M., age 33, works selling grocery products at home, earning around $4 each day in revenue. Her husband is a teacher, earning around $4 each day. They have four students who are students. She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to purchase 15 piglets to raise and buy feed for her livestock supplies.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed.

loans.name: Sipaea

texts.en: Sipaea is a 67-year-old mother of five children, all of whom have jobs. She works hard at her grocery store, which is located in the village of Vaitele and open 7 days a week, from 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Sipaea has done very well because she offers people lower prices and better quality than they can get elsewhere, and she is attracting a growing number of customers. After expenses, she earns $100 per week in profits, which she saves or uses to repay loans to SPBD. She is looking forward to her new loan, which she will use to expand her grocery store and help her family renovate their home.

loans.use: To restock her grocery store and renovate her home

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Mrs. Touch M., age 31, is a garment worker, earning $2 per day. Her husband is a carpenter, making about $2 per day. They have one child who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a motorbike for her family’s transportation and to buy a plot of farmland to grow crops.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a plot of farmland.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Touch Manh has paid this loan back early.

Thanks to your support, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to help finance their small businesses and to support their families. We hope you will continue your support on Kiva.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Mrs. Meas M., age 33, works selling grocery products at home, earning around $4 each day in revenue. Her husband is a teacher, earning around $4 each day. They have four students who are students. She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to purchase 15 piglets to raise and buy feed for her livestock supplies.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed.

loans.name: Ung

texts.en: Mrs. Ung S., age 25, works as a housewife. Her husband is employed at a hotel, earning about $6 per day. They have one child who is too young to attend school. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to finish building the rest of her house to shelter her family.

loans.use: To finish building her house.

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Mrs. Uk N., 36, is married with three children and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works on her rice paddy growing crops, while her husband works making cutting boards, earning collectively around $3.50/day in revenue. Mrs. Uk N. has humbly requested for a loan to purchase a saw and wood to facilitate and expand her husband's business.

loans.use: To purchase a saw and wood to facilitate and expand her husband's business.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Your Kiva loan has been paid back early. Your contribution has gone a long way in helping entrepreneurs like Uk Ny. We hope you will continue supporting other entrepreneurs through CREDIT MFI.

Best regards,
Isadora Tang
Kiva Fellow
Cambodia

loans.name: Try

texts.en: Mrs. Try K., age 57, works with her husband selling grocery and souvenir products, earning collectively up to $3 day of profits. They have five children, one who helps her in business and four who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase another grocery stand to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase another grocery stand to expand her business.

loans.name: Phin

texts.en: Mrs. Phin S., age 33, is employed at a private company, making $3 each day. Her husband is also employed at a company, making $5 per day. They have one child who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to build separate rooms onto her house to rent to tenants in her community.

loans.use: To build separate rooms onto her house to rent to tenants in her community.

loans.name: Ky

texts.en: Mrs. Ky S., age 24, runs a small stand at a market selling vegetables, earning around $4 each day of profit. Her husband would like to be a moto-taxi driver to earn extra income for the family. They have two children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Yean

texts.en: Mrs. Yean S., age 26, is a housewife. Her husband is employed at a private company, earning around $3 each day. They have one small child. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase a motorbike for her family’s transportation and to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her family’s transportation and to repair her house.

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Yean Sarin start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Abdullo

texts.en: Abdullo B. lives in Mastchoh; he is married and has 10 children. He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007. He is a serious and strongly motivated borrower. He is eligible for an increased loan amount because of the stability of his business and its increasing profits. He breeds and sells livestock and operates a dairy. He would like to purchase a pedigreed bull for breeding purposes and a cow for the dairy.  He plans to expand the assortment of products he sells: pasteurized milk, buttermilk, sour cream, cottage cheese, and so on. He is asking for a loan of $475 to buy this livestock, which will allow him to expand his product line and increase the family's income.

loans.use: To buy a bull and a dairy cow

loans.name: Zainiddin

texts.en: Zainiddin B. lives in Mastchoh; he is married and has 4 children. He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007. He is a serious and strongly motivated borrower. He is eligible for an increased loan amount because of the stability of his business and its increasing profits. He breeds and sells livestock and operates a dairy. He would like to purchase a pedigreed bull for breeding purposes and a cow for the dairy.  He plans to expand the assortment of products he sells: pasteurized milk, buttermilk, sour cream, cottage cheese, and so on. He is asking for a loan of $525 to buy this livestock, which will allow him to expand his product line and increase the family's income. He also intends to branch out into the business of selling beef.

loans.use: To buy a bull and a dairy cow

loans.name: Phorn

They have three children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a motorcycle for her family’s transportation and to invest in expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her family’s transportation and to invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Abdumalick

texts.en:
Abdumalick B. lives in Mastchoh; he is married and has 4 children. He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006. He is a serious and strongly motivated borrower. He is eligible for an increased loan amount because of the stability of his business and its increasing profits. He breeds and sells livestock and operates a dairy. He would like to purchase a pedigreed bull for breeding purposes and a cow for the dairy. He plans to expand the assortment of products he sells: pasteurized milk, buttermilk, sour cream, cottage cheese, and so on. He is asking for a loan of $700 to buy this livestock, which will allow him to expand his product line and increase the family's income.

He would use part of his profits to build an additional room in his home.

loans.use: To buy a bull and a dairy cow

loans.name: Thong

texts.en: Mrs. Thong C., age 27, runs a stand in front of a primary school selling biscuits, candy and other treats to young students passing by, making around $1 each day of income. Her husband works selling rice crops from their home home, earning only around $1 to $2 per day in revenue. They do not have children. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase more rice for her husband’s inventory, and the remainder to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase more rice for her husband’s inventory, and the remainder for repairing her house.

loans.name: Hom

texts.en: Mrs. Hom S. M., age 21, is a housewife. Her husband is employed at a private company, earning around $4 each day. They do not have children. She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to purchase a motor-bike for her husband to go to work. This will make his commute less expensive and quicker, as well as provide transportation for the entire family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her clothes and shoes business.

loans.name: Thoeun

She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a plot of land to grow crops to feed her family.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to grow crops.

loans.name: Len

In order to expand their inventory to meet customer demand, she would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase additional fish for her business.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of fish to sell.

loans.name: Horng

loans.use: To purchase pigs.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Horng Savorn and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

They have two children, one who is an electrician and one who is a masseuse. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a new motorcycle for her family’s transportation. This will make it easier for everyone to get to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her family's transportation.

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Tuon Oeumm start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a boat with a motor to expand her husband’s fishing business to meet customer demand. This will increase the family’s income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat with a motor.

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Moin Nuon start and sustain their businesses. Mrs.Indira T., 20, lives in Nakhu, a village located in the Lalitpur district of Nepal. Most of the people in this locality are involved in agriculture. Poultry farming is the only job Mr. and Mrs. T. have, so they rely on it to support their family. Mrs. T. sells chickens and eggs in the market. She needs a loan of US$ 175 to buy chicks to raise and feed for their chickens.

loans.use: To buy chicks to raise and feed for them

loans.name: Nikita

texts.en: Mrs. Nikita M., 25, lives in Tarankhel, Thecho (Nepal). Thecho is a village that lies within the Lalitpur district. Most of the people here are engaged in agriculture. Mrs. M. has  four members in her family including herself. Her husband, Har Kaji M., is 27. Mrs. M. has  two sons. Her elder son is 14 and is studying in class 6 whereas her younger son is 10 and is studying in class 2. Goat farming is the only profession that Mr. and Mrs. M. have so they rely on it to support their family.. They need a loan of US$ 175 in order to buy  corn flour and other feed for their goats.

loans.use: To buy feed for her goats

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mamur

texts.en: Mamur R. lives in Mastchoh. Mamur R. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007 and he recommends himself as a serious and strongly-motivated client. His loan sums are permanently increased which shows his business's stability and his income increase. He has the wide-side business including livestock raising and selling, milk production and work out. He dreams of purchasing a horn pedigree bull and a milk cow for further meat and milk and sour-milk goods production (its supply to the bazaars and his family is secure by the milk and sour products). He plans to include in the assortment the following milk and sour products: pasteurized milk, sour milk, sour cream, curd and etc. Now he requires a loan in 1600 STJ for a horn pedigree bull and a pedigree milk cow which will allow him to significantly increase his family's income and will also permits him to plan further business and a wider assortment of milk goods.

loans.use: Mamur would like to purchase a horn pedigree bull and a pedigree milk cow.

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mr. Im Chak, 49, is a father of three children and lives with his wife in Bathambnong province, Cambodia.  He works as a construction foreman, earning around $4/day in revenue, while his wife stays at home cooking food for her household. Additionally, one of his children works as a construction worker and the other two are enrolled in school.  

Mr. Im Chak plans to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle for one of his children to operate a motor-taxi whenever he is not occupied with his schooling.  Mr. Im Chak believes this will raise his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for one of his children to operate a motor-taxi so that it enables him to help increase his familý's income generation.

loans.name: Abdullobeck

He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006 and he recommends himself as a serious and strongly-motivated client. His loan sums are permanently increased which shows his business's stability and his income increase. He has the wide-side business including livestock raising and selling, milk production and work out. He dreams of purchasing a horn pedigree bull and a milk cow for further meat and milk and sour-milk goods production (its supply to the bazaars and his family is secure by the milk and sour products). loans.name: Sulochana

texts.en:
Mrs. Sulochana S., 34, lives in Tinkuna. Tinkuna is located in the Lalitpur district of Nepal. Tinkuna is very busy city of Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in business. Mrs. S. lives together with her husband and two sons. Her husband, Tika Prasad S., is a broker who sells land. Her sons are studying in grades 10 and 3 respectively.

Mrs. S. opened her cosmetics shop 3 years ago. She wants to add other personal care products to her shop because the demand is constantly increasing. Due to their economic conditions, however, she cannot invest more capital in her business. So she is asking for her first loan of US$ 175 to buy more cosmetics for her shop. Mrs. S. spends her income providing good education for her children.

loans.use: To buy personal care products for her shop

loans.name: Davronbeck

texts.en: T. Davronbeck lives in Mastchoh and he is married and has six children. He is the client of MicroInvest since 2006. His loan sums are permanently increased which shows the business stability and business income increase. Mr. Toiriv is very experienced in the livestock business and has the appropriate knowledge that he used in the practice. He has the business in the livestock raising and selling. It is the family business that brings the general family income (his wife is engaged in the milk production and other works). He dreams of the large flock and a horn pedigree bull purchasing. Now Mr.T. requests a loan of 2100 TJS for the pedigree bull purchase.

loans.use: to purchase a horn pedigree bull

loans.name: Khat

texts.en: Mrs. Khat S., age 41, is a widow who works selling fruit in Phnom Penh city, earning around $5 each day in profit.  She has five children, four of whom are students, and one who is employed at a company, making about $90 each month.  This is her second Kiva loan after she successfully repaid her first loan early.  She would like to request a loan of $400 in order to continue to expand her inventory by adding more fruits to meet customers' demands.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of fruit.

loans.name: Santi

texts.en:
Mrs. Santi A., 25, of Bhakapati (Nepal) lives in a nuclear family, together with her husband Suresh A. and one son. Most of the people in this area are involved in agricultural work. Mr. Suresh A. is a police officer and their son is in primary school.

Mrs. A. opened a grocery shop two years ago. She sells different types of grocery goods in her shop. Due to lack of capital, however, she cannot expand her business. So she is requesting a loan of US$ 250 to buy necessary goods like noodles, biscuits, etc. to expand her business. She spends her income for her son's education and household expenses.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Pum

texts.en: Pum C., age 38, works with her husband selling fish at the market, earning about $4 per day.  They have four children, two who are employed at a garment factory making about $70 per month each, one who works in Thailand earning about $100 a month, and one who is a student.  She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a fishing boat with a motor for fishing and to buy piglets and feed to breed pigs for additional income.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat and pigs to breed.

loans.name: Yut

texts.en: Mrs. Yut C. works selling vegetables at a market, earning around $3 each day in profit.  Her husband works producing palm sugar by boiling the sap from palm trees, making around $4 a day in revenue.  They have five children, of which, two work in construction each earning about $2 per day, and one is unemployed.  She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a generator for their house to improve their standard of living and allow them to work at night.  Her husband is pictured in the photo making palm sugar as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase a generator for her house.

loans.name: Ambica

texts.en:
Mrs. Ambica B. and her husband Suresh B. are both tailors in the village of Bhakapati, Lalitpur (Nepal). Tailoring is their traditional work. They learned tailoring from their parents. They make custom-fitted ladies' dresses like the Kurta Sulwar which is very popular with Nepali women.

Mrs. B. is currently asking for her second loan to buy materials such as cloth for her tailoring business. Mr. and Mrs. B. are satisfied with their income. They send their children to boarding school. They have two sons and both are studying in primary school.

loans.use: To buy materials for her work as a tailor

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Nazar

texts.en: Nazar K. lives in Mastchokh and he is married with two children. He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006 and he recommends himself as a serious and executive client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedures. He is engaged in commercial and trade service. Mr. K. has a business in agricultural products (vegetables) selling onions, potatoes, carrots, etc. He is the direct supplier which allows him to sell the vegetables at a price that is lower than the bazaar price. He is very polite which is why he has permanent clients who want to buy only his goods. Nazar K. is very experienced in his business. But working in the trade sphere he meets hard competitors which is why he wants to widen his existing assortment. Now Mr. K. requires a loan of 4100 STJ to develop his business and widen his assortment of goods.

loans.use: Nazar would like to develop his vegetable business and widen his assortment of goods.

loans.name: Tes

She has five children that she must support, one who is unemployed and four who are students.  She would like to request a loan of $1200 in order to purchase a motor-bike for her unemployed son to operate a motor-taxi business, which will enable him to earn about $5 per day and contribute to maintaining the family and paying for his siblings’ education.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike to operate a motor-taxi business.

loans.use: Abdukhamid would like to develop his business development and widen his assortment of goods for his vegetable business.

loans.name: Loeung

texts.en: Mrs. Loeung N., age 23, is single and works with her mother making bamboo baskets, earning on average around $6 a day in revenue.  She has one sibling who works as a waiter and also lives at home.  She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to purchase more bamboo for her business and to fill in the land beneath her house to avoid flooding during the rainy season.  She is pictured in the photo with her mother.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her business and protect her house from the floods.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
