Maria is a member of the Community Bank “Women for development in Pariahuanca”, and devotes herself to the sale of corn and wheat bread: she also sells peeled corn and wheat. Her business is located in the market of Huaraz province, department of Ancash, open Monday to Thursday.

With this loan of 1500 Soles, which will be repaid in 6 instalments, she will buy four sack of corn, four of wheat, one crate of butter and one sack of sugar in order to bake her breads and to make peeled wheat and corn.

She is 38 years old and she has three children, but her husband has abandoned her. Her oldest son, aged 16, helps her run the business and with the income from this she educates her children and meets household expenses.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

La señora María es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al Desarrollo de Pariahuanca”, se dedica a la venta panes de maíz y trigo, también a la venta de maíz y trigo pelado. Su negocio se encuentra ubicado en la feria de la provincia de Huaraz, Departamento de Ancash, vende los días lunes y jueves.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará 4 sacos de maíz y 4 sacos de trigo, 1 caja de manteca, 1 saco de azúcar para la elaboración de panes, también hará pelado de trigo y de maíz.

Tiene 38 años de edad y tiene tres hijos, pero su esposo la abandonó. Su hijo mayor de 16 años, le apoya en su negocio y con sus ingresos educa a sus hijos y solventa los gastos de su familia.

loans.use: Purchase of grains wholesale.  Purchase of raw ingredients.

loans.name: Maria Jacinta

texts.es:
Mrs. R. is a member of the microfinance group “Cruz de Motupe II.” She is a street vendor who sells groceries on Thursdays and Saturdays in Jr. Caraz, Huaraz province of the Ancash department.

With this loan of 500.00 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 4 monhts, she will purchase detergent, 2 cases of soap, rice, and sugar.

She is 38 years of age and has 3 children. Her income allows her to provide for her children’s schooling and to cover her household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora María pertenece al Banco Comunal “Cruz de Motupe II”, se dedica a la venta de abarrotes al por menor, ella es ambulante, vende los días de feria (jueves y sábados) en el Jr. Caraz, provincia Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará 01 paquetes de detergente, 2 cajas de jabón bolívar, un saco de arroz, y un saco de azúcar.

Ella tiene 38 años de edad y 3 hijos, sus ingresos le permite educar a sus hijos y solventar los gastos de su hogar.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries

loans.name: Catalina's Group

texts.es:
Agustina, Catalina and Eleuteria, 38, 60 and 42 years old respectively, are members of the “Dos Mil” (Two Thousand) Communal Bank. Catalina has been a Bank’s founding member for seven years.

Catalina is a peddler and sells several products, such as produce, hardware items, bread and meat. She also brings tara (a plant-derived powder used in the tanning process of leather), animals’ leather and fruits such as lucuma from local markets.

Eleuteria is also a peddler, who sells food on the street across from the police station. On Sundays, she sells clothes at the market “Feria D. las Americas”.

Agustina sells huatia, a typical regional dessert, prepared from different fruits and tubercles, such as apples, camote, oca and mashua, which are macerated in the oven. Depending on season and demand, she also sells medicinal herbs, salchipollo (a typical Peruvian dish based on roasted chicken), prickly pear and emoliente (a typical drink maD. of herbs and fruits).

In the future, they would like to have a permanent kiosk to sell their products, instead of working as peddlers. Agustina, Catalina and Eleuteria say that, at the Communal Bank, they learned to be punctual and orderly and to save in order to increase their capital and have their own permanent store. Their loans amount to 600, 1000 and 400 soles respectively, to be invested in the purchase of produce (oca, mashua, apples, camote and cane), bread, chicken, jackets, trousers and shirts. They dream of having their own capital and their own permanent space, either rented or owned, as well as buying a mototaxi for a son to work with it.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Agustina tiene 38 años, Catalina tiene 60 años y Eleuteria tiene 42 años. Ellas son socias del Banco Comunal Dos Mil. Catalina es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal hace 7 años.

Catalina es feriante y venD. diferentes productos como verduras, artículos D. ferretería, pan, carne, entre otros productos y D. las ferias trae tara, cuero D. animales, lúcuma.

Eleuteria venD. comida ambulantemente al frente D. la comisaría y además los domingos venD. ropa en la feria D. las Américas.

Agustina venD. “huatia”, un postre típico D. la zona que es preparado a base D. diferentes frutas y tubérculos como manzana, camote, oca, mashua, los cuales son sancochados en el horno. Además ella venD. hierbas medicinales, salchipollo, tuna, emoliente, dependiendo D. la época y la demanda.

En el futuro ellas quisieran tener un puesto fijo donD. puedan vender sus productos, porque actualmente son ambulantes. Agustina, Catalina y Eleuteria dicen que en su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser puntuales, ordenadas y a ahorrar para tener más capital y tener un puesto fijo. Sus préstamos son D. 600 soles, 1000 soles y 400 soles que serán invertidos en la compra D. oca, mashua, manzana, camote, candados, caña, pan, verduras, pollo, casacas, pantalones y camisas. Ellas sueñan con tener capital propio, tener un puesto fijo alquilado o propio y comprar un mototaxi para que trabaje su hijo.

loans.use: Their loans amount to 600, 1000 and 400 soles respectively, to be invested in the purchase of produce (oca, mashua, apples, camote and cane), bread, chicken, jackets, trousers and shirts.

loans.name: María

texts.es:
Maria is a partner of the Communal Bank “Divine Baby Jesus”, she is dedicated to the sale of small animals, and also she has a brick business where she sells bricks for construction. Her place of sale is the market in the Province of Carhuaz in the city of Ancash.

With the loan of 1,000 soles, which will be paid off in 6 installments, she will buy a sack of food for animals and medicines for them; also she will buy sawdust for the production of the bricks.

She is 39 years old, she has two sons, and her husband helps her in the brick factory but she manages the production and the sales.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria es socia del Banco Comunal “Divino Niño Jesús”, ella se dedica a la venta de animales menores, paralelamente tiene una ladrillera (venta de ladrillos para construcción). Su lugar de venta es en el mercado de la a Provincia de Carhuaz, Departamento de Ancash.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará 1 saco de afrecho (comida para animales) y medicinas para cuyes, también comprará aserrín para la producción de ladrillos.

Ella tiene 39 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene dos hijos, su esposo le ayuda en la ladrillera pero ella administra la producción y la venta.

loans.use: The purchase of food and medicine for young animals.  The purchase of sawdust.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Mrs. Julia is a partner of the Communal Bank “Women for the development of Pariahuaca”, she dedicates herself to the sale of grains, wheat, different varieties of corn, and hulled wheat and corn for wholesale (in sacks), her business is located at the market in the Province of Huaraz, in the city of Ancash, she sells on Mondays and Thursdays. With this loan of 1,800 soles, which will be paid off in 6 months, she will buy 5 sacks of corn to hull and 5 sacks of wheat to hull as well. She is 45 years old, she is married and has 4 children, 2 of which are independents. She lives with her husband and 2 grandchildren whom she takes care of. Her husband is a driver with his own car, thanks to it he can help her move her products to the market.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Ella es la señora Julia es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al Desarrollo de Pariahuanca”, se dedica a la venta de granos, trigo, maíz de diferentes variedades y pelado de trigo y de maíz al por mayor (por sacos), su negocio se encuentra ubicado en la feria de la provincia de Huaraz, Departamento de Ancash, vende los días lunes y jueves. Con este préstamo de S/ 1,800.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará 5 sacos de maíz cuzqueño para hacer pelado y 5 sacos de trigo para también hacer pelado de trigo. Ella tiene 45 años, está casada y tiene 4 hijos, dos de ellos son independientes. Vive con su esposo y dos nietos que tiene en su poder. Su esposo es chofer y cuenta con un carro (auto) propio, gracias a ello le puede apoyar con el traslado de sus productos hacia la feria.

loans.use: The purchase of grain for wholesale

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Mrs. Juana belongs to the Communal Bank of Mr. Cautivo II, she dedicates herself to selling spices, her business is located in the market in the Province of Huaraz, in the city of Ancash. With this loan of 1,300 soles, which will be paid off in 6 months, she will buy 10 sacks of dried yellow and red chiles, one sack of cumin, one sack of pepper, one sack of “Essence of Taste” (or MSG). Mrs. Juana is 63 years old and has 4 children, her husband left her when her children were young, she has educated them herself, now her children have grown up and are independents, two of her daughters have the same business and belong to the same Communal Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Juana pertenece al Banco Comunal Señor del Cautivo II, se dedica a la venta D. especierías, su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado D. la provincia D. Huaraz. Departamento D. Ancash. Con éste préstamo D. S/ 1,300.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará 10 sacos D. seco amarillo y colorado, 1 saco D. comino, 1 saco D. pimienta, 1 saco D. ají no Moto,. La señora Juana tiene 63 años y 4 hijos, su esposo la abandonó cuando sus hijos eran pequeños, ella los ha educado sola, ahora sus hijos han crecido y son independientes, dos D. sus hijas tienen este mismo negocio y pertenecen al mismo Banco Comunal.

loans.use: The purchase of chili peppers and spices.

loans.name: Estela

texts.es:
Mrs. Estela is a partner of the Communal Bank “Women for the development of Pariahuanca”, she dedicates herself to the sale of grains: wheat, corn, as well as hulled wheat and corn for wholesale. Her business is located in the market in the Province of Huaraz, in the city of Ancash; she sells on Mondays and Thursdays. With this loan of 1,800 soles, which will be paid off in 6 installments, she will buy 4 sacks of corn to hull, 4 sacks of wheat to hull as well, 5 sacks of corn, 1 sack of lime and 3 sacks of ash. She is 50 years old, she is married and has 3 children, 2 males and 1 female, all are older and independents. Her income has allowed her to support her children with their studies and sometimes economically support her grandchildren. Her husband helps her in this business and the income of the business allows them to pay for the expenditures of their home.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Estela es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al Desarrollo de Pariahuanca”, se dedica a la venta de granos, trigo, maíz y pelado de trigo y de maíz al por mayor. Su negocio se encuentra ubicado en la feria de la provincia de Huaraz, Departamento de Ancash, vende los días lunes y jueves. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,800.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará 4 sacos de maíz cuzqueño para hacer pelado, 4 sacos de trigo para también hacer pelado, 5 sacos de maíz para cancha, 1 saco de cal y 3 sacos de ceniza. Ella tiene 50 años de edad, está casada y tiene tres hijos, 2 varones y una mujer, ambos son mayores de edad e independientes. Sus ingresos le ha permitido apoyar a sus hijos con sus estudios y de vez en cuando apoya económicamente a sus nietos. Su esposo le apoya en este negocio y los ingresos de este negocio les permite solventar los gasto de sus hogar.

loans.use: The purchase of grains for wholesale.  The purchase of lime and ash (supplies).

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira belongs to the Señor del Cautivo II Communal Bank, and she sells leather jackets, keychains, and other products. Her place of sale is beside the Banco de la Nación in the Huaraz province in Ancash. She doesn't have a defined sales stand, that is to say, she travels around.

With this loan of 1,300 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy 1 dozen women's jackets, 1 dozen men's jackets, and 5 dozen leather keychains. Elvira is 54-years-old, is married, and has 4 children, all of whom are independent. Her income goes towards covering the family expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Elvira pertenece al Banco Comunal Señor del Cautivo II , se dedica ala venta de casacas de cuero, llaveros y otros productos. Su lugar de venta es al costado del Banco de la Nación de la provincia de Huaraz, Departamento de Ancash. No tiene un puesto de venta definido, es decir, es ambulante.

Con este préstamo de S/ 1,300.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará 1 docena de casaca para damas, 1 docena de casacas para caballeros y 5 docenas de llaveros de cuero.

Tiene 54 años de edad, está casada y tiene 4 hijos, todos independientes. Sus ingresos son para solventar los gastos del hogar.

loans.use: Purchase of leather garments and keychains

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Mrs. A. is a member of the microfinance institution “Mujeres Yungainas al Progreso.” She sells vegetables for a living, and has a produce stand located in the Yungay province fairgrounds in the Ancash department.

With the loan of 800.00 nuevos soles, which will be repaid within 6 months, she will buy wholesale celery, carrots, pickles, basil, spinach, cilantro, oregano, spearmint, and parsley for her daily sales.

She is a 25-year-old single mother of two. Thanks to this business, she has been able to push her family forward.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Elizabeth es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Yungainas al Progreso”, se dedica a la venta de verduras, tiene un puesto ubicado en el Campo ferial de la provincia de Yungay del Departamento de Ancash.

Con el préstamo de S/ 800.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará verduras y yerbas al por mayor apio, poro, zanahoria, pepinillo, albaca, espinaca, culantro, orégano, hierba buena, perejil para la venta diaria.

Ella tiene 25 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos, gracias a éste negocio ha podido sacar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: Purchase of various herbs and vegetables

loans.name: Carmelina Esabelina

texts.es:
Carmelina belongs to the Commmunity Bank of Señor D. Cautivo II. She works selling articles of clothing (trousers, jackets, blouses etc.): her sales pitch is located in a gallery on Luzuriaga Avenue in Huaraz Province, Ancash department.

With this loan of 1300 soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy a dozen trousers, a dozen jackets for the Christmas festivities and two dozen blouses.

Carmelina is 36 years old, and married with two children. Her income from the clothing sales allows her to pay the rent, educate her children and help her husband with the other household expenses.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

L. señora Carmelina pertenece al Banco Comunal Señor D. Cautivo II, se dedica a L. venta D. prendas D. vestir (pantalones, casacas, camisas y otros), su puesto D. venta esta ubicado en una Galería D. L. Avenida Luzuriaga D. L. provincia D. Huaraz, departamento D. Ancash.

Con este préstamo D. S/ 1,300.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará 1 docena D. pantalones, 1 docena D. casacas para las fiestas naviD.ñas y 2 docenas D. camisas.

ElL. tiene 36 años D. edad, está casada y tiene 2 hijos. Sus ingresos le permite pagar el alquiler D. su casa, educar a sus hijos y apoyar a su esposo en los otros gastos D. hogar.

loans.use: Purchase clothing items wholesale

loans.name: Romelia

texts.es:
Mrs. Romelia is a partner of the Communal Bank “The Mercies”, she has a juice store (sells juices and fruit extracts), her juices are sought after by the people of Carhuaz and visitors to the city. Her business is located at the central market in the Province of Carhuaz in the city of Ancash. With this loan of 1,200 soles, which will be paid off in 4 installments, she will buy 100 papaya, 50 pineapples, 1 sack of sugar, 20 units of Algarrobina (a Peruvian syrup), 10 liters of honey and a crate of milk. She is 55 years old, widowed and has 7 children, her income allows her to educate and better her family.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Romelia es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Mercedes”, tiene una juguería (venta jugos y extractos D. frutas), sus jugos son solicitados por los carhuacinos (pobladores D. la zona) y visitantes a dicha ciudad. Su negocio está ubicado en el mercado central D. la Provincia D. Carhuaz, Departamento D. Ancash. Con este préstamo D. S/ 1,200.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará un ciento D. plátanos D. isla y D. seda, 2 cajas D. manzana, 2 cajas D. naranja, 1 ciento D. papaya, medio ciento D. piña, 1 saco D. azúcar, 20 unidades D. algarrobina, 10 litros D. miel D. abeja y una caja D. leche. Ella tiene 55 años D. edad, es viuda y tiene 7 hijos, sus ingresos le permite educar y sacar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: The purchase of fruits for wholesale.  The purchase of supplies.

loans.name: Canasteras Group

texts.es:
The ladies of this group of basket makers are already experienced in the field of communal banks. They are requesting their fourteenth loan. This experience is shown in their capacity T. be organized and T. discuss among themselves when there are small objections. The fact that they already have shared more than 6 years of meetings shows that the dynamics of the group are incredible.

Mostly the ladies work embroidering blouses and traditional clothing that stem from the Guatemalan high plains. Also, there are many that invest their capital in the breeding of chickens, hogs and bulls. Another group works in the production of typical baskets of Santa Clara, while the remainder of the ladies work selling vegetables, notions and accessories in the market.

Juana E. commented that she was going T. invest her money in buying a bull in order T. fatten it and sell it for 50% more than the cost. Cristina A. is going T. utilize her loan T. buy dozens of already finished baskets and T. resell them in the market. A great portion of the ladies are going T. utilize their loans T. buy threads for their embroidery.

All these ladies dream of buying land T. be able T. expand their house, T. cultivate the land or T. offer a place T. their children so that they can build their houses in the future. These ladies, as the great majority of native women, think about the happiness of their children before their own happiness. It is for this reason that they want T. request more money than the loan that they had requested in the past: T. invest in the education of their children and daughters. Some of them dream of buying stalls inside the market so that they will not have T. walk around T. sell their products.

The dreams of these ladies are going T. be able T. come true if the necessary endorsement is given, since they have shown along the years that they can achieve incredible things with their lives. They only need T. continue receiving that support.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Las señoras del grupo Canasteras son personas ya experimentadas en el ámbiT. de bancos comunales. Ellas están solicitando su decimocuarT. préstamo. Esta experiencia se demuestra en su capacidad de organizarse y de dialogar cuando hay pequeños inconvenientes. El hecho de que ellas ya hayan compartido más de 6 años juntas, hace que la dinámica del grupo sea increíble.

En su mayoría las señoras trabajan bordando blusas y vestimentas tradicionales que provienen del altiplano Guatemalteco. También, hay muchas que invierten su capital en la crianza de pollos, cerdos y toros. Otro grupo trabaja en la producción de canastas típicas de Santa Clara. Mientras que el resT. de señoras trabajan vendiendo verduras y mercería en el mercado.

Juana E. comentó que iba a invertir su dinero en comprar un toro para luego engordarlo y venderlo a un 50% más del cosT.. Cristina A. va a utilizar su préstamo para comprar docenas de canastas ya hechas y revenderlas en el mercado. Una gran porción de las señoras va a utilizar su préstamo para comprar hilos para los bordados.

Todas estas señoras sueñan con comprar un terreno para poder ampliar su casa, para cultivar la tierra o para brindarles un lugar a sus hijos para que puedan construir sus casas en el futuro. Estas señoras, como la gran mayoría de mujeres indígenas, piensan en la felicidad de sus hijos primero que en su felicidad. Es por eso, que ellas quieren solicitar más dinero que el que ya han pedido para invertirlo en la educación de sus hijos e hijas. Algunas sueñan con comprar locales dentro del mercado para no tener que vender sus productos como ambulantes.

Los sueños de estas señoras se van a poder materializar si el respaldo necesario es dado, ya que ellas han demostrado a lo largo de los años que si pueden lograr cosas increíbles con sus vidas. Sólo necesitan seguir recibiendo ese apoyo.

loans.use: To buy and sell raw materials to embroider traditional weavings.  To buy animals for resale.  To buy baskets, raw materials to make baskets, buy vegetables and cosmetics for sale.

loans.name: Tamalii

texts.en: Tamalii is a single mother of two. The family lives in Luatuanuu center. She joined the SPBD programme in the beginning of 2006 in order to improve her fishing business. She is applying for this loan to expand her business and to improve her home. She sells the fish she catches in her village twice a week on Tuesday and Friday. She earns $130 WST ($52 USD) a day. This income helps her family meet their expenses such as church donations, bills, and food costs. The income also allows Tamalii to repay part of her loan every Monday.

loans.use: To buy new fishing gear improve her home

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is 29 years old and married with 3 children. Two of her chiildren are in school and she has a baby of one year.

Rosalina started her chicken farm business when she joined the SPBD programme in 2005. She has since paid off her first loan. She has not needed a new loan because of the good income she has generated from her chicken farm so far. However, she has just rejoined SPBD because she wants to expand her business. She is seeking this loan to buy wires and other supplies for her poultry farm. Her husband helps her with this business, and also works a taro plantation to earn extra money. He sells the produce from the plantation every two weeks. Rosalina earns $180 WST ($72 USD) a week from the poultry farm and $150 WST ($60 USD) from the taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her poultry farm

loans.name: Sioualofa

texts.en: Sioualofa is married with one child. There are seven people in her family. She is 25 years of age and is from the village Maagiagi. After she finished her school career, she stayed home to look after her family. She then found the SPBD programme and wanted to borrow money to start her elei (traditional Samoan fabric) printing business. She has experience working with elei prints. She has the skills and experience to print materials and create different designs. She estimates that she earns $180 WST ($72 USD) a week. The family not only relies on the elei printing business, but on another business as well. They have a panama and taro plantation that allows them to sell two or more tacks of taro in the market, from which they earn $240 WST ($92 USD) a week.

loans.use: To buy materials and supplies for her elei printing business

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena is 25 years of age. She lives in Papaigalagala Center. She has three children, who are all in school. She joined SPBD in order to start her ice cream business. Her business is the main source of income for her family. They all now rely on what she earns. She sells the ice cream she makes seven days a week. She earns $60 WST ($24 USD) a day.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her home improvement

loans.name: Taliilagi

texts.en: Taliilagi is 40 years old and is married with five children, who are all in school. Her business was started when she joined SBPD at the end of last year. She started by selling ice cakes. She now also makes and sells pancakes. She sells her pancakes two days a week at the primary school in her village. Her husband helps her in the business because there is a lot to do every morning and afternoon. They earn a profit of $110 WST ($44) a day. This money helps meet her family's needs and expenses such as church donations, food expenses and phone bills.  The money will also help her send her children to school and to pay back what she owes SPBD. Taliilagi is a hard working mother.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her pancake business and for home improvement

loans.name: Lolakovati

texts.en: Lolakovati is 29 years old. She is a mother and lives in Papaigalagala Center. She joined SPBD last year in October to start a pancake business. She is a hard-working mother, who delivers the pancakes she makes every day to the village primary school. She earns $400 WST ($160 USD) a week, and after all expenses she gets a profit of $150 WST ($60 USD). This money allows her to repay part of her loan every week. She is looking forward to future loans so she can continue to expand her business. She would also like to use some of the money to renovate her home.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her pancake business and for home improvement

loans.name: Faafou

texts.en: Faafou is 48 years of age and married with 4 children. They live in the village of Vaitele. Before she joined SPBD last year, Faafou played bingo every Friday to earn money. After she joined SPBD, she began her sewing and elei (traditional Samoan fabric) printing businesses to earn extra income.  Now the businesses are doing well and she is looking forward to her next loan. She will use this loan to expand her business and renovate her house. She earns $250 WST ($100 USD) of profit weekly.  The income she earns allows her to repay her loan and also to save money for her family needs like food, bills, and other financial obligations.

loans.use: To expand her businesses and improve her house

loans.name: Puapae

texts.en:
Puapae is 29 years old. She is a single mother with one child. She runs her own elei (traditional Samoan fabric) printing business in Vaimoso, where she lives. She is one of the longest running members of SPBD. Her first loan in 2004 helped her to start her elei printing business. She is good at printing and also making different designs, which is why people buy from her at the market.

Paupae is now applying for her fifth loan so she can expand her business, improve her home and also help the family grocery shop. She earns a profit of $200 WST ($80 USD). She will use this money to send her child to school, meet her family's needs and pay back what she owes to SPBD.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her elei printing business and for home improvement

loans.name: Anave

texts.en: Anave joined SPBD in 2004 to start her ice cake (popsicles in a bag) business. After two months she earned more money than she had before and she started to expand her business. She began to sell items like fish and chips in a fast food stall so she could continue to help her family. It has been almost four years, now, and she has moved into a new house, which is a big improvement. Anave and her family live in a healthy environment now because of her hard work and ability to save money. Anave earns $350 WST ($140 USD) in profit weekly. She is requesting this loan to buy more supplies to sell in her fast food stall.

loans.use: To buy potatoes, oil, fish, chicken, pepper, flours, pots, and other supplies for her fast food stall

loans.name: Faatau

texts.en: Faatau is 38 years old and married with 3 children. Like most women, she has a flea market plot.  She sells her own handicraft clothes and other items like footwear and hair accessories in her stall.  She sells her handicrafts six days a week in the flea market at Fugalei. This earns $110 WST ($44 USD) daily.  Her husband earns some money, too, and together they make a good deal of money in a week. They are able to improve their living conditions and generally meet their family's needs. Faatau would like to use this loan to buy supplies and inventory for her flea market sales.

loans.use: To buy supplies and inventory for her flea market

loans.name: Ulalia

texts.en: Ulalia is 40 years old and from Tulaele. She has four children. She is one of the best-known tailors in her village and the surrounding villages. Ulalia specializes in sewing puletasi (the traditional Samoan garment worn by women), t-shirts and any other kind of style. She also makes beautiful and unique elei (traditional Samoan fabrics) prints for individuals and groups or organizations, like church youth. Her husband also earns extra income for their family from his work.  Ulalia is looking forward to this loan so she can expand her sewing business and improve her home.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her sewing business

loans.name: Makerita Talosaga

texts.en: Makerita enjoys running her fast food stall to sell food to the public.  She has curry, chicken fried rice, and umu (talo, banana, and luau with turkey tail). Her stall is open Monday, Tuesday and Friday only.  Makerita earns a profit of $330 WST ($132 USD) per week.  Makerita will use her loan to buy ingredients for her fast food stall and also to send her children to school.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her fast food stall
